debateSection.name: topical
debateSection.heading: Saincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Debate

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Crime Prevention

speech.p: I rise deeply saddened by the horrific murders that occurred in Edenderry on Saturday evening. Two innocent lives were taken - Mary Holt, aged 60, and four-year-old Tadhg Farrell. I wish to pay my respects to Mary and Tadhg. May they both rest in peace and may their memory guide our response through this moment of darkness. I visited the scene and it is something I will never forget. A room recently alive with an excited young heart giddy with the joy of Christmas, toys imagined, stockings planned and innocence undisturbed now stands as a haunting reminder of a future robbed. The silence was heavy. The air felt cold carrying the memory of a terror no child should ever face.

The people of Edenderry are not just grieving, they are angry, heartbroken, traumatised and confused. I firmly believe the true weight of this tragedy will fall most painfully when the town sees a tiny white coffin - heartbreakingly small - carried to its final premature resting place. In that moment, the darkness of what has happened will become real in a way none of us ever wished to witness.

This did not come from nowhere. This is down to drugs and the drugs trade. It is glamorised in music, film, social media and entertainment. It is portrayed as fast money, status, power and designer labels. Hard working people see individuals who have never worked a day in their lives live with the trappings of wealth. They ask themselves, "What am I doing wrong?" Young people see this and believe it is success. However, the truth is not glamour. It is terror, drug debt, threats, children being groomed into criminality. It is soulless, selling misery, addiction and violence for profit. It destroys families, businesses, relationship and hope. It underpins so many of the issues we debate in this Chamber - housing, poverty, mental health, domestic abuse, crime and inequality. The raw reality of that world without filters or fantasy burnt a four-year-old child alive on Saturday. That is the cost; that is the truth.

While nothing can undo this tragedy, we can influence what happens next. I have complete confidence in the gardaí. They will find those responsible. When they do, the full weight of the law must land heavily on them. Justice must be seen, and justice must be felt. However, justice must also mean prevention. It must mean restoring confidence, protecting children and rebuilding peace.

I sincerely acknowledge the work the Minister for justice is doing in his Department in terms of gardaí recruitment. It matters and I thank him for that. However, given what has happened in Edenderry, I ask the Minister to request the Garda Commissioner to examine the establishment of a dedicated task force for Edenderry focused specifically on dismantling drug-driven criminality. I am not directing but I am respectfully asking that it be considered.

People deserve protection in life, not only in law. They deserve peace in their homes and on their streets. They deserve the right to enjoy the simple things like sitting in their own sitting room to watch television without fear. We owe that to Mary and little Tadhg. We owe that to every resident in Edenderry.

speech.from: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport (Deputy Charlie McConalogue)
speech.p: I thank the Deputy for raising this. On behalf of the Minister for Justice, Home Affairs and Migration, I thank him for addressing it on the floor of the Dáil. I join the Minister, Taoiseach and the Deputy in strongly condemning the deliberate callous attack on the house in Edenderry, County Offaly, over the weekend which tragically resulted in the loss of the lives of Mary Holt and young Tadhg Farrell. I join with the Deputy in extending my deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Mary and young Tadhg on this absolutely unacceptable travesty and loss of life. There is no place in a civilised society for such heinous violence.

An Garda Síochána has commenced a murder investigation into all the circumstances surrounding this fatal attack. I join An Garda Síochána in appealing to anyone with information to come forward. The gardaí have given assurances they will relentlessly pursue the violent and dangerous criminals for this murderous attack. They will be brought to justice. I appreciate that this incident will be shocking to people in the community in Edenderry and across the country and may naturally give them pause for concern about their own safety. I reassure them that the gardaí are following a direct line of inquiry and they have a strong record of bringing dangerous and violent criminals to justice.

It has been well reported that gardaí suspect criminals involved in the drugs trade in the midlands may be behind the most heinous act. Tackling the scourge of drug dealing and targeting the work of organised crime groups who inflict intimidation, violence and misery on families and communities across Ireland is a top priority for the Government and An Garda Síochána.

The Deputy mentioned Garda resources. The Government is investing record amounts in An Garda Síochána to ensure the Garda Commissioner has the resources he needs to tackle the illegal drugs trade. A Garda budget of €2.59 billion for next year will fund the recruitment of up to 1,000 new gardaí, 200 more Garda staff and a doubling of the Garda Reserve to over 600 next year. A total of 794 garda recruits entered the Garda College across 2025, the largest intake in a year since 2018. Significant numbers of gardaí have attested from the Garda college throughout this year and as more probationary gardaí attest across 2026, all communities will see a benefit as they are assigned out to their stations.

Ultimately, the Commissioner will make the decision on where Garda resources are assigned but the Minister is assured that a number of factors are taken into account, including crime trends in an area, demographics and local resourcing requirements. I assure Deputy McCormack that in relation to the heinous and murderous act we saw at the weekend that resulted in the tremendously tragic and unacceptable loss of lives, no stone will be left unturned. Every avenue will be explored to make sure that those responsible are brought to justice.

I want to acknowledge the wider trauma surrounding this event. Another woman remains in hospital with serious injuries. Her life has been changed forever and she will need support in ways we cannot measure yet. I also want to acknowledge the first responders, gardaí, paramedics and Offaly fire service officers who entered that scene. They faced what most people could not. They acted with courage and humanity and they deserve recognition and support for the trauma they now carry quietly on behalf of us all. Neighbouring families are shaken. Children in the estate are frightened. Homes that should be now filled with Christmas excitement are instead filled with fear and unanswered questions that no parent should ever have to answer.

Edenderry Garda station does not operate on a 24-hour basis. Edenderry now needs reassurance through action by way of a visible policing presence and strengthened Garda numbers. Criminals do not operate on office hours and safety should not either. I ask that Edenderry Garda station would operate 24 hours a day. Let this tragedy be the moment that confidence is rebuilt in Edenderry, not the moment when we simply mourn or move on.

I join Deputy McCormack in extending my thoughts and prayers to the lady who was injured in the attack. I wish her a speedy recovery. Deputy McCormack's point in relation to Garda resources in Edenderry and Offaly is massively important. I understand that at the end of October, there were 399 gardaí assigned to the Laois-Offaly Garda division, a 45% increase on ten years ago. They are also supported by 51 Garda staff who provide really important support to gardaí and free them up to focus on front-line policing duties. Eight probationary gardaí were assigned to the Laois-Offaly Garda division this year and 12 probationers were assigned last year. It is also worth noting that An Garda Síochána operates a divisional model which means that it uses all of the resources within the division, not just the Garda station within a particular community, to respond to local demands on the service it provides.

We can see throughout our communities the damage and devastation that organised drug crime groups heap on society, not least in Deputy McCormack's local community over this past weekend. Tackling the issue of drug-related intimidation is a high priority for An Garda Síochána. Nominated Garda inspectors are available throughout the country through the drug-related intimidation reporting programme to assist victims of intimidation. In addition, the drug-related intimidation and violence engagement, DRIVE, project, which launched earlier this year has established effective systems for assisting those affected by drug-related intimidation. There are over 400 publicly-funded drugs services, including family support services, across the country which can advise and support people affected by drug-related intimidation. Family support services are critical because drug-related violence nearly always becomes an issue for the whole family. There is more information available for anyone who needs support on the [driveproject.ie] website

I thank Deputy McCormack again for raising this today and assure him that the Minister for Justice and Home Affairs and the Garda Commissioner will do everything they can do bring the people responsible to justice.

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Departmental Schemes

speech.p: The warmer homes scheme is supposed to protect the most vulnerable households in our society, including older people, low-income families, people living alone and those wholly dependent on supports like the fuel allowance. Right now the scheme is failing them and it is about to get far worse. I will outline the current reality. On 4 November this year my office contacted the SEAI on behalf of a vulnerable client who applied for the warmer homes scheme in October 2024. Almost 14 months later she is still awaiting a survey or an allocation. The timelines are staggering. It is taking 14 months to get a survey, 26 months for works and another three months for post-works inspection. This is not a functioning scheme. We already have 20,000 homes on the waiting list. The Minister of State knows as well as I do that these are not discretionary upgrades. These are essential measures for people at risk of fuel poverty.

The critical point that I want to emphasise is that the number of people on the fuel allowance, the key qualifying criteria for the warmer homes scheme, is expanding dramatically. From next year those on the working family payment will be eligible. That is an additional 50,000 households, bringing the total number of fuel allowance recipients to more than 500,000. If nothing changes, the warmer homes scheme waiting list will surge even further because eligibility will expand faster than delivery capacity. This is not a projected problem; it is an inevitability. The SEAI currently has no action plan, no surge capacity, no backlog reduction strategy and no timeline for clearing the existing 20,000 cases. Money is not an issue but delivery is and telling people that we have increased funding is meaningless if funding does not translate into workers on roofs, contractors on the ground, insulation going into walls and people living in warmer homes.

When will a full, published action plan be produced to address the backlog of 20,000 homes? What contingency planning has been done for the additional 50,000 homes that will become eligible under the expanded fuel allowance scheme? Will the Government commit to a maximum six-month waiting time for a survey for any applicant on the fuel allowance? Will the Department intervene directly to ensure that the SEAI increases contractor and surveyor capacity immediately? We cannot keep telling vulnerable people to wait three winters for a warmer home. We cannot expand eligibility by 50,000 households while pretending the scheme can cope as it stands. This requires urgency, action and leadership now, not later.

I thank Deputy Murphy for raising this issue today. The climate action plan includes targets to retrofit the equivalent of 500,000 homes to a building energy rating, BER, of B2, cost optimal, and the installation of 400,000 heat pumps in existing homes to replace older, less efficient heating systems by the end of this decade. The national retrofit plan sets out the Government's approach to achieving those targets. The programme for Government 2025 contains a number of commitments in relation to retrofitting. They include delivering more B2 equivalent home retrofits each year from 2026 to 2030, with a focus on lower-income households, improving the provision of grants and financing models for home owners, including older people who wish to retrofit, enhancing energy efficiency and reducing costs, as well as supporting group retrofitting projects.

The warmer homes scheme aims to improve the energy efficiency and warmth of homes owned by people at risk of energy poverty by providing fully funded retrofits. The scheme is operated by the SEAI on behalf of the Department and is funded through carbon tax receipts and the European Regional Development fund, ERDF Last year saw a record spend of almost €230 million under the scheme.

As reported by the SEAI, this resulted in 7,743 upgrades being provided to lower-income households. This year's budget includes an allocation of €250 million for the scheme, which is a €50 million increase. That represents an elevenfold increase on the 2020 expenditure figure.

The scheme has been delivering a greater number of deeper and more complex upgrades in recent years, and this is reflected in the average cost of upgrades, which the SEAI indicates has increased from €2,600 in 2015 to over €29,000 this year. These deeper upgrades mean that more lower-income households are benefiting significantly from warmer, healthier and more comfortable homes with lower energy bills and reduced emissions.

With regard to waiting times, which I know are key to the point the Deputy is making, increased awareness of the multiple benefits of retrofit and improvement to the warmer homes scheme is driving increased levels of demand for the scheme, with just over 45,000 applications received over the period from January 2022 to the end of October 2025. Over the same period, more than 24,500 homes have been upgraded under the scheme. We had 45,000 applications and in the same period, 24,500 homes were upgraded.

For homes that have been allocated to a contractor for works under the scheme so far this year, the average waiting time was just under 15 months. Once a home is allocated to a contractor, the completion times can vary based on the types of works being undertaken at a home and the lead time for ordering and delivery of materials and products, such as windows, are factors. Homeowner availability for upgrades in their homes can also be a factor. The average waiting time from application to completion of upgrade works to date in 2025 has been 21 months for the worst performing homes and 22 months for better performing homes. It is important to note that these averages represent a significant reduction since the first half of 2022, when the average waiting time was 27.5 months.

The reduction in waiting times follows a range of measures introduced by the Department and the SEAI, including the allocation of additional staff to the warmer homes scheme, a significantly increased budget allocation and active contract engagement with management by the SEAI to increase contractor output, as well as actions to address ongoing supply chain pressures. A pilot delivering additional homes from the warmer homes scheme waiting list under the energy efficiency obligation scheme was introduced last year.

Importantly, the SEAI launched on 8 December a procurement process to establish a new €1.2 billion contractor panel to be in place by quarter 2 next year. This will support continued growth, with a focus on scale, quality and output under the scheme. Department officials continue to work with the SEAI to further accelerate and maximise the output of fully funded energy upgrades with the objective of minimising wait times.

I thank the Minister of State for his reply, which alluded to a 21-month waiting time. Correspondence sent to me directly by the SEAI confirmed that the waiting time is somewhere between 24 and 26 months. People came into my office in quarter 3 of 2024 and as of now, 14 months later, the SEAI cannot tell me when these homes will be surveyed. I have people in their 90s who applied in quarter 3 of 2024. They will not be alive when their house is due for a survey.

I appreciate the Minister of State's reply, but there is no concrete or time-bound plan. Nothing will change for people who are currently waiting for years for essential upgrades and insulation. I cannot understand why we cannot get the surveys done quicker. Not every house needs a heat pump or a new set of windows. Sometimes houses just need insulation. I cannot understand why we cannot deliver insulation upgrades within six months. The expansion of the fuel allowance to those on the working family payment would see a surge of 50,000 new houses qualifying for the warmer homes scheme. If we expand eligibility without expanding delivery capacity, we will simply deepen frustration, lengthen queues and worsen energy poverty.

There are, I say again, 20,000 homes on the waiting list. If nothing changes, these numbers will only go in one direction, which is upwards. I am telling the Minister of State that I will be here again next year and there will be 30,000 homes on the waiting list. It will take 16 or 18 months for a survey. It will take more than three years for full completion of works and vulnerable people cannot wait for three years. We need a backlog reduction task force, emergency procurement of surveyors and contractors and a fast-track system for the elderly and particularly high-risk households. This is about dignity, fairness and the basic right to a warm home. We need timelines, capacity and an action plan or the scheme will continue to fail the very people it was created to protect. People in their 90s who applied in quarter 3 of 2024 will not be alive when their houses are due for a survey.

I will relay the urgency of the need to increase the capacity to the Minister and the Department as a result of this debate. As I indicated in my previous contribution, we have seen a significant increase in the number of applicants. The number has gone from 3,000 homes in 2021 to 13,500 in 2024. There has been a massive increase in the number of applicants, which is obviously putting on pressure by way of demand. It is important that the capacity to deal with that and to deliver on this scheme matches the demand levels and the budget that has been allocated every year, which this year has increased, as I said earlier.

The other challenging factor that is influencing waiting time is the fact that deeper retrofits are taking place. That is reflected in the increase in cost from €2,500 ten years ago to €29,000 now. That is reflecting the fact that a lot more is happening whenever a retrofit is taking place.

The important piece, which will have a positive influence and will help to address the important point the Deputy is addressing, is the fact that the SEAI has put in place the procurement process for the new warmer homes contractor panel, which commenced in recent months. It is anticipated that it will attract additional capacity for the programme over the next four to five years. That tender carries an estimated value of €1.1 billion, representing a record programme of commitment for that five-year period. The SEAI expects to have the contractor panel in place for quarter 2. Its objective will be to support that continued growth with a focus on the scale, quality and output.

The SEAI also continuously monitors the performance of all contractors operating under the warmer homes scheme, including in relation to the quality, level of complaints, timelines and general administration.
I will certainly feed back the Deputy's key points to the Minister and the Department. I will emphasise the importance of ensuring that capacity continues to increase.

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Hospital Facilities

speech.p: I thank the Minister of State from being here. She is from the relevant Department, and I appreciate it. That should be the norm in this House. It used to be.

An exceptional piece of journalism was published last week by the Limerick Leader. The front page article spoke about the catastrophic failures in University Hospital Limerick, UHL, which we have discussed in the House. No other topic have I discussed more in my political career. The picture on the front page shows four young women. I compliment the journalist, Ms Sandra Quinn, and the Limerick Leader for what they put out. Sometimes a visual says more than words. The story is about Ms Aoife Johnston and Ms Niamh McNally, both 16, Ms Eve Cleary, 21, and Ms Leona Cusack, who was 33. They all died because of what is going on in UHL.

I will say something of the Government with all the positivity I can. I know what I am talking about. I have spoken about my family in the Dáil on numerous occasions. I have spoken about my dad, the anniversary of whose passing was two days ago. He did not want to go into UHL. I have spoken about my neighbours and friends. I spoke recently about a situation where I had to ring and somebody in the HSE told me once I got on the motorway to go to Portlaoise hospital, which I did. That was an emergency and the patient got fantastic service. The Government has a huge decision to make. In fairness, the Minister, Deputy Carroll MacNeill, has said she will make that decision next week. She met mid-west Deputies and Senators two weeks ago. Unfortunately, for some reason, Deputy Sheehan and I were not invited so I must raise the issue on the floor of the Dáil.
The HIQA report was not necessary, but we have it because Mr. Gerry Burke, who was the former lead clinical consultant in UHL, did all the statistics ten years ago.
The situation has only got worse. Even in terms of the HIQA report, the census data is out of date. We are totally discriminated against.

If you look at the south east, which the Minister of State is very familiar with, there are three model 4 hospitals in Waterford, Wexford and Kilkenny. There is also one in south Tipperary. We have one. That is not sustainable. The idea that the people in Clare, Limerick and north Tipperary have only one accident and emergency for 450,000 people is insane. The only decision that can be made next week, along with option A of the 96-bed block and option B of building a 100-bed unit nearby, is to make the decision long term. We need ambition to have a model 3 or model 4 hospital in the mid-west. Anything else will continue this discrimination and I will not be part of another generation of politicians who stand up in this House and accept that.

It is discrimination. My phone was ringing all weekend about cases in Limerick. Despite the new 96-bed block, the numbers there are 110 on trolleys and 31,000 on waiting lists. We have a worrying situation where consultants, because of the working conditions, are leaving. I urge the Minister of State to give the Christmas news everybody in Tipperary, Limerick, Clare and even parts of north Cork want to hear and that is that we will do all the short- and medium-term planning and we will look again at the pathways regarding minor injury units and open them up as well as open up community services but for God's sake, we need another hospital in the mid-west. It is as plain as the nose on my face. Any other decision is discrimination and is totally wrong. I will be the first person to stand up and congratulate the Minister of State if she delivers it.

speech.from: Minister of State at the Department of Health (Deputy Mary Butler)
speech.p: I thank Deputy Kelly for the opportunity to address the House on the discussion around the need for a new model 4 hospital in the mid-west region. I also thank him for his ongoing advocacy in relation to University Hospital Limerick. I have stood across the floor from him many times over the past five and half years discussing health matters, and he has been very consistent. I want to put that on the record.

In May 2024, HIQA was requested to conduct a review of urgent and emergency care in the mid-west region, with the primary objective of ensuring safe, quality, acute care. As part of this review, HIQA was requested to consider the case for a second emergency department in the context of the population changes in the region and with the ongoing pressures at UHL. HIQA submitted its final report to the Minister, and it was published on 30 September this year.

As the Deputy will appreciate, the reports and analysis supporting this review are extensive. There was substantial stakeholder engagement, regulatory inspections, a national policy review, data analysis review and international evidence reviews. The Minister and I acknowledge the substantial work undertaken by all those who both conducted and took part in this review, including the expert advisory group which included a wide representation of relevant experience.

In summary, HIQA’s analysis found the inpatient bed capacity in the region needed to be increased to meet current and projected demand for patients requiring more complex or specialist healthcare. I acknowledge UHL is still the busiest hospital, with a 10% increase in attendance this year compared to the last year. I had a conversation with senior management this morning and they are on track to receive 100,000 attendees to the emergency department this year. Mitigation pieces are in place regarding senior clinician decision-making and de-escalation of the emergency department, with a good length of stay averaging at four and half days. Thankfully, mortality is static and currently in line with every other hospital.

I recently visited the mid-west region to discuss mental health and I compliment the mental health teams. The CAMHS teams there have turned around the complete waiting list and are now operating much better. I also visited University Hospital Limerick and met with the regional executive officer, Sandra Broderick, and senior management. I visited the new 96-bed block and I am delighted to say it is open, which the Deputy has welcomed publicly. The second one will be up and running as soon as possible. However, this does not solve the short-term issues.

This morning there are 32 people on trolleys in UHL - three in the emergency department and 29 moved to wards. This is similar to other areas. In Galway, there are 51, in Cork, there are 39, and in the Mater, there are 27. Certainly, every focus has been put in place to try to reduce that.

Going back to the HIQA report, it presents three options, as the Deputy knows, with the expansion of capacity at UHL on the Dooradoyle site, which is option A; the extension of the UHL hospital campus to include a second site in close proximity, which is option B; and option C, which is the development of a model 3 hospital in HSE Mid West. The Minister has accepted the report and the advice from HIQA. Along with her officials, she is considering the comprehensive and detailed reports and advice provided by HIQA and will report back to Government before the end of the year.
The ESRI has projected the number of inpatient beds to meet the projected 2040 demand will need to increase from between 299 and 593 beds compared with 2023 capacity levels.

I thank the Minister of State for her response and I acknowledge the improvements that have happened in UHL in the past couple of years. However, we have serious issues when it comes to staffing and high-level consultants as regards attracting them, given the situation the hospital is in.

Politics has failed the people of the mid-west on this issue. I am not going to start blaming certain parties but politics has failed across this House. Consultants helped drive the agenda to close the units in Ennis, St. John's and Nenagh. Then, they disappeared off the face of the earth and were never found again. Politics now has to come back and fix it. This Chamber has to fix it; the Minister of State's Department has to fix it. We cannot fail the people of the mid-west continuously as we head into Christmas again, with people who live alongside me afraid. We cannot fail the families of these four poor women and others. I could give the Minister of State hundreds of examples of issues there.

The Minister of State spoke about the volume of beds required, which I absolutely accept but how in the name of God can we create those beds without creating a new hospital? I am not even arguing for Nenagh, Ennis or wherever; I just want a decision that we need a new hospital in the mid-west - an access point with beds and critical infrastructure. We cannot go on the way we are. We need that ambition and I am afraid this is being choreographed, that the decision being made next week will be options A and B but not C. I have no issue with option B as long as that decision to create another 100 beds has a hospital wrapped around it in years to come.

The Minister for public expenditure is from the Minister of State's party. I urge the Ministers for Health and public expenditure, Deputies Carroll MacNeill and Chambers, in the next week before the Cabinet decision is made - it has to be made because the Minister has promised it - that this decision will be long term and that we will create a new model 3 or 4 hospital in the mid-west to end the discrimination and fear. There are people who will not go into UHL because of the fear they have and the situation we have been left in.

I thank the Deputy for that. The Minister will update her Cabinet colleagues before Christmas on her considered response. I acknowledge the fact the Deputy appreciates there is work going on to increase capacity and additional funding has been provided. UHL's budget has increased from €265 million in 2019 to €507 million in 2024. I will also touch on the two rapid build 16-bed units opened in December 2024 and June 2025, respectively, and the 96-bed block that was opened in October 2025, which the Deputy spoke about, to provide an additional 128 beds in the region, since the ESRI assessment of capacity in 2023. This has already helped reduce the number of people waiting on trolleys, notwithstanding the pressures all hospitals are currently facing due to the increased presentations by people sick with the flu. A second new 96-bed block is in progress at UHL and a third 16-bed block is planned for 2026.

Bed capacity has been further expanded throughout the region, through the acute hospital inpatient bed capacity expansion plan, including 24 new beds at Nenagh Hospital, 48 new beds at Ennis Hospital and 42 new beds at St. John's Hospital.

It is expected that there will be at least an additional 420 beds in the region by 2031. Other initiatives for the region include the acute virtual ward for 25 patients, which went live in UHL in July 2024. I will also touch on the staff, especially those working in the emergency department with the constantly increasing presentations every day. They are the front line and do a phenomenal job.

However, I take on board every word the Deputy said. I know people are waiting in anticipation for the Minister's response. She has said she will bring it to the Cabinet before Christmas and I will speak to her after this debate to let her know about the Deputy's strength of feeling. Everyone accepts and acknowledges that there is not enough capacity of acute hospital beds in the region at the moment. I thank the Deputy again for his advocacy.

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Schools Building Projects

speech.p: I wish to raise the long delays in a rebuild project that three schools in my constituency are facing. They are St. John Bosco Junior Boys School, St. John Bosco Senior Boys School and Mary, Help of Christians Girls National School. These schools are just off the Navan Road in Dublin 7. They serve the communities of Ashtown, Navan Road and such new communities as Pelletstown. They are great schools. I have had the opportunity to visit them. I have met the student council of St. John Bosco school and I had the chance to see just how run-down those old buildings were. They are musty, prefabricated buildings with single-glazed windows and cold classrooms.

They are three distinct schools, but they have come together with a vision for an education campus on the site. The Minister of State will be aware that bringing three separate schools together under one project is a challenge, but such is the commitment of the school management teams that they have done it. They have a definitive plan for how the students would move out of sections of the old school, how those sections would be demolished and how the new school would be built across the site over a period. However, there has been a real blockage in the schools getting past the notorious stage 2a of the Department's processes. This was an election issue in the general election this time last year and, as soon as I was re-elected, I asked a parliamentary question of the then Minister in February this year. There was due to be a meeting between the schools and the Department back in March. That was cancelled quite abruptly.

The situation to date is that the Department requested a stage 2a addendum report from the school's design team, which advised the Department at least four weeks in advance of that report that it would come in on 30 October 2025. Despite having significant notice from the school design team, the Department did not allocate any time or resources to review the documentation when it was received. A meeting had been scheduled by the design team with the Department in anticipation of progressing the review, but again, the Department cancelled the meeting and informed the schools the documentation would now not be examined until after the new year. This is extremely disappointing, particularly given the three schools were explicitly assured that this project would move to the next phase in the first quarter of this year.

I acknowledge that the Department sought additional detail and amendments through the addendum, but the lack of preparation on the Department's side to review that documentation when it came in raises serious concerns. I know and the school knows that the Department school building team is under real pressure, but it is now more than a year that these schools have not been able to get past stage 2a. The school and its design team are working quickly and efficiently and are keeping the Department up to date on progress at every stage. However, the Department is not replicating that level of engagement. These three schools, St. John Bosco Junior Boys School, St. John Bosco Senior Boys School and Mary, Help of Christians Girls National School, need a firm date as early as possible from the Department on which to meet the design team, agree the addendum report and let these schools progress to the next stage. Can the Minister of State give me a firm date for when this meeting will take place?

I thank the Deputy. I am taking this Topical Issue matter on behalf of the Minister for Education and Youth, Deputy Naughton, to outline to the Dáil the current position of the joint school project for St. John Bosco Junior Boys School, St. John Bosco Senior Boys School and Mary, Help of Christians Girls National School in Dublin 7. The joint school building project the Deputy outlined the background of will deliver two new 16-classroom primary schools, with additional classrooms for children with special educational needs for the senior boys school and the girls school and a new 11-classroom primary school with additional classrooms for children with special educational needs for the junior boys school.

Initially, it was anticipated that this joint project would be delivered in the form of an extension and refurbishment. However, due to a scope change to include an increase of classrooms for children with special educational needs, it was decided that new school buildings would be provided. The design team submitted the initial stage 1 report in April 2023 and, following the submission of an addendum report in August of that year, the project was approved to move to the next stage.

The design team submitted its stage 2a submission report to the Department in January 2024 for review. Upon review, some key concerns were identified by departmental officials and the school authorities and design team were advised in advance that, in place of the stakeholders meeting, there would be a further interim stage 2a workshop to discuss and assist the design team in progressing its stage 2a submission in a positive manner. The design team was asked to complete a review and audit of the floor area schedules and to refine some design elements in order to meet the approved schedule of accommodation. A further interim workshop was held on 22 March 2024 between the Department and the design team architect, where further refinements and adjustment to floor area were discussed.

Upon receipt of the revised stage 2a report, departmental officials carried out an initial review and arranged an architectural workshop with the design team lead in May of this year to discuss it further. In early June 2025, a further meeting was held with the wider design team, school authorities and departmental officials in attendance. At that meeting, the school was provided with a progress update and advised that the design team was due to submit an addendum stage 2a report to the Department. The outstanding information for the addendum stage 2a report was received in the Department on 31 October 2025. Departmental officials will carry out a full review of the addendum report and the stakeholders' meeting will be scheduled once the review is completed.

In July, the Government announced a capital allocation of €7.55 billion for the Department of Education and Youth for the period 2026 to 2030 under the national development plan, NDP. As part of this NDP allocation, the Department will place a strong emphasis on provision for children with special educational needs, with a particular focus on meeting annual school place needs. The approach to project roll-out for large-scale projects and additional school accommodation scheme projects will be to continue to maximise the capacity of the existing school estate as much as possible in the first instance and provide necessary additional capacity through targeted and prioritised project roll-out over the course of the 2026-30 period to meet the most urgent and prioritised needs.

I thank the Minister of State for the update, but I am disappointed that he, or the Department of Education and Youth, is not in a position to give a clear date for when the schools' design team will meet the Department to, first, discuss the latest addendum report submitted by the schools and, second, give them permission to move past stage 2a. In the speech the Minister of State read, we see that the initial stage 1 report was submitted in April 2023 and it was followed by a stage 2a submission report in January 2024 and a workshop in March 2024, and then we jump to another workshop in May 2025. My concern is that this is not progressing with the degree of haste the situation in these schools requires. Let us remember - the Minister of State read it out just now - that the initial proposal, even before 2023, was for an expansion and refurbishment of prefabricated buildings.

The Department itself, however, identified that the condition of all these school buildings was so poor that a complete demolition and rebuild of all three schools was needed. The Department identified that, yet we see this delayed process taking place.

There was a commitment for a meeting prior to Christmas. That meeting was cancelled and now there is no firm date for when it is going to take place. I understand this is not the Minister of State’s Department, but I ask that he reflect back to the Department of education the absolute urgency of having a firm date for when this meeting can take place so that these three schools can move past the stage 2a process and the children in them can have a hope of seeing the rebuilding during their time in them.

I certainly will bring that back to the Department and to the Minister and the Deputy’s emphasis on the urgency of moving this project on. I know that whenever three schools are brought together for one project like this, it is a big commitment on behalf of all three schools. It is not easy to keep everybody on the one page and it is important the project keeps moving. I will reflect back to the Department and the Minister the full content of what the Deputy has been saying.

As I said in my previous response, the Department asked the design team in early June this year to submit an addendum stage 2a report to the Department. This was received on 31 October 2025, some five or six weeks ago. The departmental officials will be carrying out a full review of that addendum report. They are committing to a stakeholders meeting being scheduled once that review is complete. This is where the process is at now. I take on board the points made by the Deputy in terms of the urgency of completing that review and giving clarity in terms of when the meeting will happen and having it happen so that the process can then move forward.

On a wider note, to summarise where we are at generally and where this situation sits within the wider overall investment plans, which are going to be important in terms of moving this and other projects forward, €6 billion has been invested since 2020, as the Deputy knows. This has seen 1,300 school projects completed. In 2025 to 2026, 80% of new special classes are being facilitated in repurposed classroom accommodation, so there is particular pressure in respect of addressing that need. Departments, including the Department of education, are currently in the process of publishing their sectoral NDP implementation plans. The sectoral plan for the Department of Education and Youth will be published next week and the first tranche of projects to progress to construction will be published in January 2026. This NDP implementation plan will optimise outputs from the national development plan allocations, with a strong focus on maximising existing school capacity, progressing priority projects where local capacity across schools and areas is insufficient and ensuring delivery that is affordable, offers value for money and meets functional needs.
I certainly will feed back the full content of the Deputy’s contribution and the need for the prioritisation of this project.

debateSection.name: debate
debateSection.heading: Dog Welfare (Amendment) Bill 2025: Second Stage [Private Members]

speech.p: I move: "That the Bill be now read a Second Time."

The Minister of State and I both know that Ireland is a nation of dog lovers. We love our dogs and we love our pups but the reality is many people in Ireland would be absolutely horrified if they knew what the back story of those pups was. They would be disgusted to know that those pups came from a nightmare situation the pup's mother is probably still living through. It is where a pregnant female dog can be bred over and over again in horrific conditions that are dirty, cramped and cold, often with not enough water or light, and where she is matted, covered in sores and not getting any care, love or human interaction. That dog is just seen as this production line to pump out pup after pup.

These terrified mother dogs are breeding absolutely terrified pups. What happens in that instance is not only does the mother dog have horrific health problems but the pups have horrific health problems and often have behavioural issues. Those pups are sold to families who are so looking forward to having this gorgeous little bundle of joy in their home. Instead, they get a dog, a little pup, that has never been socialised and may never have had much human interaction because these pups are often fed by automatic machines. This pup then becomes a difficulty and a real challenge for these families, one they are sometimes not able to deal with. It is a conveyor belt of misery and it has huge animal welfare concerns.

Puppy farms are a profit model gone absolutely mad. It is a real example of an industry that can gain a huge amount of money at the expense of vulnerable animals but where there is not sufficient oversight of regulations. Rescues are left to pick up the pieces of this and they are exhausted. They are tired and finding it so hard to deal with the number of pups and dogs that are being abandoned at the moment. These are all run by volunteers. They are the ones who get the mother dogs who arrive matted and terrified into their care. They are the ones who get the puppies who are too old to be cute any longer and therefore the breeder cannot sell them, so they dump them. They are the ones who get the puppies that are brought in by families because they were given up due to health or behavioural issues. It is all down to a lack of regulation.

Many people will be very surprised and shocked to learn that, at the moment, there is no cap on the number of female dogs that can be in a puppy farm. The legislation envisages there are over 300. It would be incredible to have that many breeding females and their pups on-site. Not only that, there is no mandated number of staff required to be there to look after those pups. We can really see where the difficulties set in. Female dogs can have up to six litters in their lifetime. Dogs as young as four years old, when they are only puppies themselves, can be forced to have their own pups. The dog welfare Bill the Social Democrats are bringing to Second Stage today strengthens the 2010 Act by capping the number of breeding females on-site at 30. It introduces a 16-month minimum age and eight-year maximum age for breeding; a maximum of one litter per year per breeding female; a maximum of four litters per breeding female during her lifetime; a minimum age of ten weeks for pup separation; and mandates a one to ten staff-to-animal ratio for proper care. It also outlaws surgical artificial insemination and other harmful practices.

This is a modest Bill. We are not coming into this Chamber saying every single puppy farm in the country should be shut down. We want them to be properly regulated and we want the welfare of dogs and pups to be at the centre of this. This Bill will go a long way to ensuring that we are caring for those dogs properly. I am interested to hear what the Minister of State has to say. I hope that the Government can work with us on this. It is something that has huge support from the public and that they really want to see happen. I thank Dog Law Ireland for its support for this Bill, as well as Dogs Trust and Wicklow Animal Welfare, which I have worked with very closely over the course of this. I also give a shout-out to all those rescues who put in so many hours looking after our animals.
I thank my colleague, Deputy Jennifer Whitmore, for all of her work on this issue and all of her passion on it.

Ireland's dog breeding system operates without any real oversight or much compassion and it desperately needs to be addressed. Something many people are not aware of is that we are the puppy farm capital of Europe. Thousands of dogs are exported from here every year and flown all over the world. It is ridiculous, cruel and incredibly lucrative. We need restrictions on the number of breeding dogs and the number of litters they can have over their lifetime. Without that, the system will continue to encourage breeders to push dogs way beyond their limits. We all know what the consequences of that are: dogs kept in appalling conditions and not getting the treatment they need; dogs who spend every waking minute terrified and in pain; dogs who are not socialised and have serious behavioural issues; and puppies that are born into simply horrendous conditions.

The current staffing guidelines are absurd. It is recommended there is one staff member for 25 breeding females. If each of those has a litter of six, we are talking about one person being expected to care for 175 animals. That is not animal welfare; it is systemic neglect. Dogs need care and attention. They need to be fed, watered and loved. No one person can provide that for 175 dogs. Breeding standards should prioritise welfare over profit. Anyone working in animal welfare will tell you the same thing because they are the ones who are picking up the pieces of a system that encourages people to mass-produce animals like they are products to go on a shelf. Rescues are held to strict standards. They face inspections, audits and endless paperwork and scrape by on tiny grants from the Department of agriculture. Meanwhile, another arm of the same Department gives out breeding licences with almost no limits. How can a Department demand rigorous standards from those saving animals while giving free rein to those churning them out? It is completely ridiculous.

Skibbereen Animal Rescue was founded in 1998 by Anita Douglas, who sadly passed away last year. She was an extraordinary woman who cared deeply for the animals in her care. During the pandemic, she took out a loan and used her pension to cover the costs to do this. That is who this broken system leans on. People like Anita hold everything together while puppy farms flourish. We need to fix this and we can. We need to cap the number of breeding bitches, restrict the number of litters, fix the staff ratios and fund rescues properly. If we want to be serious about dog welfare, we need to catch up and we need to do it now.

I commend the work of Deputy Whitmore in preparing this legislation that has come before us today. "We're full and still they come" were the words of Limerick Animal Welfare in the media yesterday. It described 2025 as unprecedented, with a year-round surge in puppies and kittens being surrendered to it. This is in advance of what it and many other rescues will see in the swathe of animal surrenders, mostly dogs, in January and February of next year. Rescues are doing a remarkable job on behalf of this State but to meaningfully address this problem requires strengthening the legislation. My colleague, Deputy Whitmore, has introduced evidence-informed legislation that would go a meaningful way towards ending the cruel practices currently facilitated by a lack of regulation in Ireland.

For most of us, the only way to try to stamp out puppy farms is to not give them the business they need to continue but this Government can do a whole lot more than that. I isolate the role of local authorities here. Are councils resourced to really enforce the current legislation when it comes to unauthorised developments, specifically with regard to puppy farms? Are we resourcing councils with adequate dog wardens and facilities in this regard? Ultimately, are we taking this issue seriously enough?

More than that, the Government could choose to facilitate this Bill going to Committee Stage to debate its merits and talk in detail about what strengthening it would look like. This Government likes to be the best and top of the class in European comparisons. Ireland is the capital of puppy farms and puppy deportations. That is not a list we want to be top of and this legislation would meaningfully address that.

I thank my colleague Deputy Jennifer Whitmore for her work on this Bill. Her work in bringing this proposed amendment forward is a step towards ensuring that dogs and puppies are treated correctly. I also thank Dogs Trust and Dog Law Ireland for their work to make sure that dogs are given a chance to be loved and treated properly. As I said yesterday during the briefing in the audiovisual room, how we treat our dogs is so important because they are sentient beings. This is a political issue. In fact, I would say it is a "pawlitical" issue that can no longer be ignored.

As my colleagues have all said, Ireland having the horrific title of being the puppy farm capital of Europe is not something that any of us should be proud of. Breeding puppies for profit and forcing mother dogs to be continuously pregnant to produce puppies is just beyond cruel. In the audiovisual room yesterday, Dogs Trust told people about the state of the mother dogs and puppies that come to them when rescued. They told of the horrific conditions that these unscrupulous breeders are keeping the dogs in. I have to say that it was sickening to the stomach. Ireland is supposedly a country that loves its animals but, having heard what we heard yesterday in the audiovisual room, I really doubted that, to be honest.

If people knew what was really happening on puppy farms, they would think twice before buying a puppy. This Bill and Deputy Whitmore's work will, I hope, bring closer the reality of people realising that the cute little puppy they are getting may have had a shocking start to life that affects every part of its life. It may mean that the puppy fails to thrive and may die prematurely.

I am imagining the number of puppies that will be gifted this Christmas. I am also imagining the joy of somebody getting a little puppy at Christmas - or any time of the year but apparently it happens a lot at Christmas. I do not agree with this because dogs are for life and not for Christmas, as one advertisement used to tell us long ago. When puppies have that shocking start to life, they have a reduced chance of survival. If a puppy is failing to thrive, imagine the huge vet bills a family could wrack up trying to save the little thing's life, and then it dies. If children are involved, there will be absolute heartbreak. I am a mother of four and we have had pets that reached the end of their lives. It devastates children, but this is preventable. Deputy Whitmore's Bill sets out to prevent cruelty against poor puppies and their mothers having lives that are absolutely awful. It is a start in that process.

It is often said that a dog is man's best friend. In Ireland, we are no different. Who of us do not remember the old stories of Cú Chulainn, who was named after the hound, or Fionn mac Cumhaill and Bran? There are nine Irish breeds of dog, the most famous being the wolfhound. We have a proud and long history in our mythology and society of a wonderful relationship with dogs. Unfortunately, we also have a history of cruelty to animals in this country. Less than six months goes by in any year, and we hear of some conviction, investigation or a tragic case of animal cruelty being uncovered. These disproportionately involve dogs. Dog farms are not the only area of animal cruelty. We see it in fox hunting, the treatment of greyhounds by unscrupulous people, dog fighting and the inhumane treatment of farm animals.

At the heart of this Bill is not a question about how dogs should be treated but, rather, how we, humans, must act with care not cruelty, with connection not exploitation, in harmony with animals rather than only seeking to profit off them. It should be known in this House that the psychology of those who harm animals and exploit them is often a precursor to more violent and exploitative actions against other humans. It has been very well documented across the psychiatric profession and in research that if one is cruel to small animals in particular, it is a leading indicator of cruelty, antisocial behaviour and disorders. In particular, cruelty towards dogs can often be a precursor to sociopathy. This Bill is crucial in addressing human behaviour, ensuring we are good stewards of the animal kingdom and especially for those we call our best friends. At its core is also the question of how a society should behave. How we treat animals is how we will eventually treat our planet, our fellow human beings and, indeed, ourselves.

It is the great false narrative that somehow animals are precluded from the rules that govern societies. That is not the case. There is a natural cycle of things, yes, and of how animals are predators and prey, eat and are eaten, are part of our domestication and are undomesticated. That natural cycle can be twisted to the cruel and inhumane. That is a reflection of us, of our humanity and our role in a planet we share with the animal kingdom and, ultimately, of who we become.

Let us be the best version of ourselves, the one that values and cares for dogs and other animals, one that prevents cruelty and does not tolerate it, one that corrects injustices and does not turn a blind eye, one that ensures that we live up the better angels of our nature, our humanity and the concert in which we live with all living beings. Let us make sure we make Ireland a great place for dogs.

speech.from: Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine (Deputy Noel Grealish)
speech.p: I thank Deputy Whitmore for bringing this Private Members' Bill before the Dáil. As an avid animal lover, I agree with a lot of what is in her Bill. I hope we can work together to implement it. The Minister for Agriculture, Food and the Marine, Deputy Heydon, has asked me to relay his apologies for being unable to be here this morning, and to clearly state that the area of animal welfare broadly, as well as that of dogs specifically, is of utmost importance to both him and his Department.
On behalf of the Minister and the Government, I am putting forward a 12-month timed amendment to the Dog Welfare (Amendment) Bill, a Private Members' Bill, the reasons for which I will outline.

The Government fully recognises the significance of this policy area. The timed amendment allows time for the deliberative processes relevant to the area we are discussing, and that are already in train, to reach their conclusion. The Minister is confident these processes will come to a landing zone that will be well aligned with many of the principles of this Private Members' Bill, as introduced and clearly and passionately articulated by Deputy Whitmore.

Before I reference those processes, I will provide some background information and context with respect to the issues at hand. Deputies will be aware it was a programme for Government commitment that the somewhat disjointed approach to dog control issues be addressed by ensuring all legislation and policy in relation to the control of dogs, dog welfare and dog breeding establishments rest with the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine. In this respect, it is positive to be able to report and confirm that policy responsibility for dog control was transferred to the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine from the Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht, with effect from 1 June 2025, and for dog breeding establishments on 1 August 2025. It is important to note that local authorities retain responsibility for all operational and enforcement matters. They have the power to appoint dog wardens, provide dog shelters, seize dogs, impose on-the-spot fines and take court proceedings against owners.

The Government's commitment to this area is exemplified by the enhanced funding across a number of streams. The Minister asked me to reference near-term funding initiatives in the animal welfare space, including the provision of the now annual tranche of funding to qualifying animal welfare charities, which include several dog charities. Furthermore, the Minister was also pleased to recently confirm that local authorities will continue to be resourced into next year, to the tune of €2 million overall, with respect to the retention or appointment of additional dog wardens in 2026.

Coming back to the proposed 12-month timed amendment to Deputy Whitmore's Bill, the rationale for this is to allow for sufficient time for the Minister and his Department to consider the outcomes with respect to two deliberative processes that are ongoing in this area, both of which will inform policy and legislative considerations from public, stakeholder and expert perspectives.
The first is a public consultation process, which is ongoing, to inform consideration of the next Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine animal welfare strategy for the period 2026 to 2030.

At the launch of that public consultation last month, the Minister indicated that animal welfare is a topic of enormous and growing importance, both to farmers and to the broader public in respect of how society values and treats all animals, including dogs. He went on to say that as the bar in respect of animal welfare continues to rise, he wants to hear opinions and how his Department's next animal welfare strategy can put Ireland on a best-in-class footing with comparator countries, while maintaining the progress, as evidenced by our achievements to date.

Moving on from the second deliberative process, the Minister asked me to highlight, with respect to the policy specifically on dog control and breeding, that a high-level dog control stakeholder group was established in 2024 to consider policy and legislative matters in dog control, breeding and welfare areas, which includes consideration of legislative provisions under the dog control Acts and the Dog Breeding Establishments Act. The report and recommendations of the dog control stakeholder group are anticipated in early 2026. The Minister is awaiting the deliberations, report and recommendations of the group, which has been meeting quarterly to consider numerous issues in the dog control and breeding space, including, but not limited to, legislative change.

The Bill set out by Deputy Whitmore focuses on the specific aspects of policy that have formed part of the deliberations of the dog-control stakeholders group, and in particular the work of one of the sub-groups which, as part of the process, has spent significant time specifically focusing on dog-breeding establishments. The Minister hopes and trusts that Deputy Whitmore will accept his modus operandi when he asked me to relay that this timed amendment put forward by the Government is less about the merits or demerits of her Private Member's Bill, as proposed, and more about the Minister acting in the future upon processes that this and previous Governments set in train. The Minister has indicated he is very happy to consider the need for legislative change in this space and will engage proactively with all interested parties in doing so.

I want to compliment Deputy Whitmore. I heard her outlining the purpose of her Bill on "Morning Ireland" this morning. She has a lot of support on this side of the House. I am an avid dog lover myself. I take in rescue dogs. In the little area where I live, there are more dogs than people. I know Deputy Whitmore is very passionate about this, and I know her party is very passionate about it. It is an area that has to be addressed, and it has to be addressed soon. I know the Deputy is anxious that something be brought forward before the 12-month period. We will push to do that, but I will ask that the officials meet with Deputy Whitmore and brief her on where everything is at and make sure she is consistently contacted and kept informed on what is happening. I would like us to work together. I know the Deputy is very passionate about reducing the time. I cannot give a commitment on that now, but I will ask the officials to meet with her and see if we can reduce the timeframe on that. I will get back to her on that. If I can get back to her before 12 noon, I will. I thank the Deputy for bringing this Bill forward; it is a very important one. I hope the House and the Government will be able to bring something forward fairly soon.

speech.from: An Cathaoirleach Gníomhach (Deputy Aengus Ó Snodaigh)
speech.p: Gabhaim buíochas leis an Aire Stáit. Casaimid anois go dtí na Daonlathaithe Sóisialta.

I congratulate Deputy Whitmore on a brilliant piece of work. While I welcome that the Government is not outright opposing this Bill - I do appreciate that and we all welcome it very much - I have to say it is frustrating and disappointing because we hear this line consistently from the Government that we do not put forward solutions, and yet the last three pieces of legislation this party has put forward have all been served with timed amendments. They are not complex pieces of legislation that would require the Government to do that. To me, it really feels like these are being kicked down the road, unfortunately, when essentially there is no reason we cannot progress to the next Stage and deliberate more fully. I would say the same of our previous Bill, which was to reduce the voting age to 16, for which we know there was Government support from certain Members, and of our Bill that originated in the Seanad to provide free transport to victims of gender-based violence. As a new TD, it is something that really stands out for me.

When my team and I meet voters in Rathdown, we are always meeting people with dogs. These are pets that are treasured family members. They are vital companions for many in our community. They are well cared for and loved and they enjoy safe homes and kind treatment. However, not far from the border of my constituency, at Mount Venus Road, many animals are cared for by the NSPCA. These are dogs that have experienced the most cruel treatment and neglect. Although we love our animals, we have to do better in protecting them, and this Bill allows us to do just that.

Ireland has earned a shameful title as the puppy farm capital of Europe. It is not a badge of honour; it is a stain on our conscience. The Bill put forward by Deputy Whitmore will end the cruelty, secrecy and profiteering that has defined this industry for far too long. Every year, 30,000 puppies are churned out like products on a factory line. They are shipped from Dublin to places as far away as Singapore, and while the puppies are sold for thousands of euro, their mothers are left behind in cages, forced to repeat the cycle again and again until their bodies give up. This is not farming; it is the mass production of misery.

The Dog Breeding Establishments Act 2010 was supposed to protect animals but instead it opened the floodgates. Many councils appear to have handed out licences rather than confront the logistical challenges of seizing dogs. This legislation is facilitating, instead of regulating, large-scale commercial dog breeding, and now Ireland has become the world's supplier of designer puppies - cavapoos, pomskies, cockapoos; cute names masking ugly realities. Obtaining a licence to breed in Ireland does not guarantee animal welfare. A fully-licensed farm can have one staff member responsible for 175 dogs and still be in compliance. We have seen dogs living in piggeries, fish boxes and their own filth, and we have seen puppies sold online, only to drop dead within weeks because of bad breeding and a terrible start to life. Families are then left heartbroken, children traumatised, and the animals themselves suffer unspeakably.

While the cruelty is obvious, the economic crime is hidden. Tens of thousands of dogs are sold each year, often for €500, €1,000 and €5,000 each. Much of this trade is unregistered and untaxed. This is money that could instead be funding inspections, veterinary care or public services. This unregulated puppy farming is not just animal abuse; it is a thriving black market. We cannot keep pretending this is a niche problem. It is a €120 million industry. It is global and growing. If we do nothing, Ireland will continue to export cruelty for profit. If we act, Ireland can show that we genuinely care about animal welfare. A puppy is not a product. A kennel is not a factory. Animal welfare is not optional.
I will begin by thanking Deputy Whitmore not only for bringing forward the Bill, but also for the passion she brings to the area of animal welfare.

I refer to the idea of a 12-month delay. We will work with the Government because of the importance of the issue, but we need to get beyond simply kicking the can down the road. Let us start the immediacies of working together.

I am very proud to talk about this animal welfare Bill because it also gives me an opportunity to talk about my dog, who I have been dying to talk about in the Chamber for a very long time. My dog is called Ethel and she has no problems in life. She gets walked several times a day and she gets the comfiest bed. Sometimes she allows me to sit on the couch. This dog has no issues at all. However, about two and a half years ago, she got gastroenteritis. She ate something in the park, got an upset stomach and was brought to the vet. The vet up in Cabra treated her amazingly but gave her a little shot in the back with a little needle. Every day since that day, when she walks past that vet, her stride hurries, her tail goes between her legs and she starts to shake a little bit because that was a time in her life when she knew a little bit of pain. I think about that when I consider the context of this Bill to address female dogs being forced to breed constantly from the age of six months, which is incredible to think of. I think about the emotional pain as well as the physical, because these are emotional beings. They are emotionally intelligent. My dog knows when I am not having a good day, so she definitely knows when she is not. I think about the dogs who are in these kennels being forced to breed constantly, as if they are a factory churning out litters. The inhumanity of that is something that sticks with me when I think about the kindness of all of our pets and little animals. We should be rushing to remove that from ourselves. The length and breath of this country, one will find people whose pets are part of their family. The idea that Ireland remains the puppy farm capital of Europe is unconscionable to that little being that sits at our feet and shares our food and home. We need to act with as much pace as we can.

Let us work collaboratively on this because it seems to contradict what we all know. Ireland cannot continue with these puppy farms. It cannot continue to have a greyhound industry, which, while a separate issue, is also seeing dogs destroyed constantly. We have to do better because these pets are little friends at home. We cannot continue to have another side industry in which exploitation, cruelty and harm are built in. I want to work with the Minister of State and I know Deputy Whitmore wants to work with him and the Minister, Deputy Heydon. Let us do that quickly.

I commend my colleague, Deputy Whitmore, on introducing this important Bill, which, if not obstructed, will greatly strengthen our dog breeding regulations. Unfortunately, it seems the Government is kicking the Bill into touch, which means it will be in limbo for 12 months at least. It is important to say that the Government is prone to frequent whinging that if only the Opposition could make constructive suggestions instead of complaining, it would happily work with us. This is patently shown up here, as with so many other Bills, for the disingenuous claptrap that it is.

Currently, the welfare, breeding, sale, supply, control and traceability of dogs fall across multiple Departments, including the Departments of Agriculture, Food and the Marine; Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht; Justice, Home Affairs and Migration; and Housing, Local Government and Heritage. This level of fragmentation ensures dog breeding remains essentially unregulated and wide open to abuse.

It is estimated that around 100,000 puppies are bred in Ireland each year. Irish people love dogs and are willing to invest significant sums of money to welcome a puppy into their family. Unfortunately, this demand is very often exploited by some breeders who prioritise profits and care not a jot for animal welfare. Many puppies and their mothers are born into miserable, nightmarish environments where they may be kept in confined spaces with inadequate light, limited human contact and substandard care, including restricted access to food and water. Deputy Whitmore’s Bill represents a first step towards regulating breeding operations and providing protections for puppies and their mothers. The Bill proposes limits on the number of breeding females, the age at which dogs can breed, the age at which puppies may be separated from their mothers, the implementation of staffing ratios and a prohibition on surgical artificial insemination.

I will focus briefly on surgical artificial insemination. This procedure carries welfare and ethical concerns, including risks associated with general anaesthesia and surgical complications. Non-surgical alternatives are widely used internationally and are not associated with many of these risks. The UK, Norway, Sweden and the Netherlands have banned surgical insemination for welfare reasons and the Veterinary Council of Ireland’s code of professional conduct also discourages its use on ethical grounds. This is just one aspect of Deputy Whitmore’s Bill, but one that highlights the far-reaching favourable impact the legislation could have on dog welfare. The question that remains is why the Government is deferring this Bill for 12 months. I can so reason other than political pettiness.

I thank Deputy Whitmore and the Social Democrats for bringing forward this legislation. It is an appropriate time to introduce it given the work being done by the stakeholder group to look at all of these issues. The Government is talking about kicking the can down the road, as it does with so many of the Bills that come before the House. We all need to recognise that we have a difficulty in Ireland when it comes to puppy farming. That said, my understanding is that there is considered to be a market in Ireland for approximately 50,000 puppies per year, about half of which come from registered puppy farms.

To be a breeder in Ireland, you have to have more than six bitches. An awful lot of the people who are providing or selling pups have one or two dogs. Usually, they love and care for their dogs very well, particularly in those small environments. However, that is not always the case. There are always dogs in those environments that are looked after very badly. I have some experience of this. We had dogs at home and I remember the pups coming. On one occasion, they were Irish wolfhounds. We are up at night watching the dogs and waiting for the pups to come. This went on for two nights in a row and when they were born, we had to get a box with a red lamp in it, similar to a small incubator, and put the pups into it to keep them warm. We had to get up every two or three hours and feed the pups because otherwise the bitch would lie over them and possibly kill them. We had to be there with them all the time. It is an intense thing to do. I cannot imagine how difficult that must be if someone has 30 bitches. Of course, that would not be happening to all of them at the same time, but it is a big operation in those circumstances.

My understanding is that there are fewer than 20 breeders in Ireland who have more than 30 bitches. While the number is quite low, that does not mean these operations do not need to be regulated and intensively monitored. A limit is certainly needed but that needs to be worked out. The Bill refers to a figure of 30 and maybe there are arguments around that. We need to hear what those arguments are and see what the situation is.

The number of pups going to the UK has been very large for the past ten to 15 years, although I think the figure has gone down somewhat in recent years. That is part of the work the stakeholder group needs to do. I know it is meeting and doing work on that. We need to get reports from the group and accurate data to know exactly what is happening, how it is happening and what is in place around the country.

Of course, there are circumstances in which people are very careless in how they look after these animals and see them only as a means of making money. In my experience, the vast majority of people who breed dogs are not like that. They care and work with the dogs and follow up after they sell a pup, ringing the buyer a month later, six months later and a year later to ask how the dog is doing. They have an affinity with the dogs and look after them very well. That is reflected back, and we hear that from the vets, the people who know what is going on. In most cases, they are also the people who will sound the alarm and let the authorities know when there is a problem. In fairness, the local authorities and county vets in most areas are active. The county vet in my area is extremely active in ensuring that things are done properly and there is not the kind of abuse we have seen in the past and which is happening now to a limited extent.

The proposals in the legislation are apt, particularly around insemination. There are issues there that clearly need to be dealt with. The Minister of State said he hopes to deal with this legislation within the year, if not sooner. The sooner the better because it needs to get absolute attention. Everyone, in every corner of these Houses, has an affinity with dogs. People love their dogs and have a great sense of companionship with them. We used to always say that no matter whether you came home in good humour, bad humour or whatever way you were, the dog would come to welcome you wagging its tail. They are always there to welcome people. That sense of affinity we have with these animals will, I feel, give us the strength, as a community and a nation, to ensure we have adequate legislation in place, including on following up. There is no point in having the legislation if we do not follow up and implement the regulations to ensure animals are treated properly. This has to be done with authenticity and must not be something that is swept under the carpet or hidden away.

The number of bitches a person needs to have registered to be a breeder may need to come down. Numbers and limits need to be put in place with haste. I hope the Minister and Government come forward with measures very soon.
I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Dog Welfare (Amendment) Bill. I thank Deputy Whitmore for putting it together and bringing it before the Dáil.

At its core, the Bill seeks to close serious gaps in the Dog Breeding Establishments Act 2010, which is outdated legislation, and place welfare, not commercial-scale breeding, at the centre of how we regulate these establishments. For too long, the absence of a cap on the number of breeding females has created the conditions for large-scale puppy farms, where animals are treated as units on a conveyor belt rather than living beings with needs and instincts and the right to basic care and welfare. Sinn Féin has been very clear that the current regime is being abused, albeit by a minority of operators. Without a statutory limit, establishments can accumulate very large numbers of breeding bitches with no realistic capacity to provide proper welfare.
