A cap of 30 breeding bitches is necessary to end the worst excesses of intensive dog breeding operations. As has been noted, without proper regulation and staffing levels, no individual or small operator can manage the welfare of 30 females and their many pups, never mind the far higher numbers we know exist in some facilities around the State. This Bill both acknowledges that reality and seeks to remediate it.

We also strongly support raising the breeding age. Allowing pups to be bred from six months old is entirely inappropriate. They should be left to mature. We want to see the minimum breeding age increased to 15 months. Furthermore, pups must be allowed to remain with their mothers for at least ten weeks.

The current practice where pups are separated after only a few weeks in order to bring the bitch back into breeding condition is harmful to both mother and pup. A statutory ten-week mother and pup period is a basic welfare requirement and long overdue. The introduction of a staff-to-bitch ratio of 1:10 is also welcome and without that clear staffing requirement, welfare obligations cannot be enforced in any meaningful way. Proper oversight, staffing and inspection regimes are needed if we are to be in any way serious about ending cruelty and exploitation.

I want to address the issue of surgical artificial insemination. The changes to the code of professional conduct for veterinary practitioners have already recognised the welfare concerns involved. However, the continued exemption for greyhounds is not justified. The same welfare standards should apply to all dogs and Sinn Féin believes the law must reflect that.

We have seen it in the last Government, which was dubbed the kick-the-can-down-the-road Government, and it is unfortunate to see that, despite the new injection of Independent Deputies into the Government benches, this is continuing. We saw it with wind turbine regulations last week and we see it with this piece of legislation this week, where the can is kicked down the road. I understand the points the Minister of State outlined in his speech to allow that discursive element to take place but we need to grapple with this issue now. This Government is 11 months ar an bhfód and we need to get to grips with this. I ask the Minister of State to allow this to go ahead.

I am delighted to speak in support of this Bill on dog welfare. I am a proud mammy of two beautiful fur babies, Benji and Frankie Byrne, and I was half tempted to hold up their pictures here today and ask how anybody could be so cruel or neglectful to little creatures like that. The Long Title of the Bill reads: "An Act to provide for animal welfare considerations in the operation of dog breeding establishments, including but not limited to a cap on the number of breeding bitches, the age of bitches allowed to breed, the age of pups when removed from their mothers, a staff-to-bitch ratio, and to prohibit the use of surgical artificial insemination [That is, apart from greyhounds].

There is nothing that makes me cry quicker than to read about the poor treatment of dogs and the breeding of bitches and puppies on some of the so-called puppy farms this legislation seeks to address. Any true dog lover knows just how much attention a pup needs, never mind a litter of puppies or multiple litters. The fact that there are currently people out there keeping multiple mothers and litters in unsanitary and unsupervised premises in 2025 is just unbelievable. The Bill puts on a statutory basis the need for a staff-to-bitch ratio of 1:10. Personally, I think that should be lower but we are here to support this Bill.

Sinn Féin recognises the change to the code of professional conduct for veterinary practitioners to prohibit veterinarians from carrying out surgical artificial insemination in dogs due to ethical and welfare considerations. However, this does not apply to greyhounds, and I and Sinn Féin believe it should also include greyhounds. Leave the pups with their mothers for the first ten weeks. Let them play and be fed, watered, nurtured and looked after properly until they can make someone the happiest person in the world when they are picked up and brought to what is hopefully their forever home. We need to close any sort of loophole that could be exploited with regard to animal care but we support the Bill.

I welcome this Bill being brought forward. It is actually quite common sense. It could have gone further but I respect that the Deputy is trying to make a really big first step, which is important. We are now being recognised as the European capital for breeding dogs and pups. There are a lot of things we want to be top of the list for in Europe but that is certainly not one we want to be seen as, especially when we are a people renowned for our history with dogs. I was listening to other people talk. The joke in our house is that I go home on a Thursday evening and when I go in the door at whatever time it is, 8 o'clock or 9 o'clock, our little dog Coco is waiting at the door for me shaking her tail off. My two daughters are shouting "Hi Dad" down the stairs and my wife Michelle is probably busy doing something. There is a special bond. I remember when we got Coco I was running in the by-election. I came home one night after canvassing and she was in the kitchen with my two daughters and my wife. Michelle said to me, "Sure you are out canvassing anyway and the girls will have Coco while you are out", and what could I say.

I have had dogs all my life and so has my wife. A dog is like a family member. I know some people might condescendingly ask, "What do you mean by that?" but for anyone who has a dog, there is a special bond when you have a dog in your house. I know sometimes when my daughters are doing exams and when they are down, if the dog is upstairs, she is up in one of the bedrooms. There is a bit of comfort in having that companionship and only a dog can give it sometimes.

I welcome this Bill. It is really important. Another point I want to make is around the housing crisis and the number of people getting evicted. People ask what that has got to do with dogs and breeding. A lot of people who go into emergency accommodation cannot take their dogs with them, so they either have to give their dogs to a family member or give them away. These are consequences of the housing crisis and homelessness. A lot of landlords now will not take dogs. I am not sure if it can be included in this Bill or in another piece of legislation but I believe people need rights to bring their pets with them, obviously in a controlled way. They should not be barred from renting accommodation because they have a pet or a dog. We want to see these proper regulations. We do not want to see some of the horrendous things that are happening with breeding at the moment.

I live in Gurraunbraher now. I remember when growing up there were dogs everywhere. There would be dogs running loose all the time. People have evolved and there is a lot more respect for dogs among the vast majority of people but there is a small minority and they cannot be let get away with it.

I thank Deputy Whitmore for bringing this legislation forward. I heard her on the radio this morning. You could hear that she is coming from a really good place on this and the passion she has for it. It really comes across and the Deputy is pushing an open door with this legislation when it comes to me. We need regulation. In any industry, when there is no regulation, it can lead to a wild west situation where anything goes. This is particularly worrying when it comes to animal welfare.

The legislation around current dog breeding practices is being abused. For example, as was mentioned, there is no cap on the number of breeding bitches that a breeding establishment can have. I really do not like using the term "bitch", so I will call them "mother dogs". For example, as the Deputy said this morning, you could have up to 300 mother dogs on one puppy farm. We have heard reports of how the mother dogs are being kept in cages. We have heard how they are being fed by automatic feeders. They are lying in their own excrement and they are not getting any socialisation whatsoever.

Breeding practices within these puppy farms frequently lead to serious health issues for the puppies. These practices can lead to genetic disorders and infectious diseases and the lack of human interaction can result in significant behavioural issues. These inhumane conditions not only cause immense suffering for the dogs but also contribute to the broader issues of overpopulation and the abandonment of unhealthy or unmanageable dogs. More often than not, it is dog rescue organisations that have to pick up the pieces.

New owners of puppy-farmed puppies and dogs can have a hard time when they bring their dog home, with illness or unwanted behaviours. It can lead to additional costs for the owner and also additional expenses in regard to veterinary care and the emotional turmoil of seeing a dog and puppy in distress and being unwell. Nobody wants to see this. Nobody wants to see an owner having to give up their dog. My partner has a beautiful whippet called Padmé. I will give her a second name like Deputy Byrne did. We will call her Padmé Murphy. She is a rescue dog - a beautiful dog who had a really difficult start in life. She is boisterous and energetic. She is full of energy and an absolutely beautiful character. She brings so much joy into our lives and as was mentioned before, the welcome you get from a dog when you walk in the door is second to none. I would love to see my children copy the dog and give the same welcome I get from Padmé when I come in. I would never stand up here and call Padmé a "bitch". My life would not be worth living. In fact, I just about get away with not calling her a baby. I hope I will get a few brownie points for bring her up here today as well.

There are so many other dogs out there that do not get the same chance in life that Padmé has had, in being brought into a loving home. Despite some issues at the start of her life, she has a loving, warm home where is part of the family. It is horrific to think that there are businesses and puppy farms out there that are making huge amounts of profits on the back of overbreeding puppies and dogs. We need to put regulations in place to make sure this does not continue. I know the Minister of State mentioned kicking it down the road.
I will try to bring it back.
I have brought forward at least two pieces of legislation here this year and there have been timebound amendments to them, so we need to have a bit of urgency on this as well.
I am sure if I were to ask everyone in here to raise their hands, including the kids in the Gallery, if they do not like dogs, those who do so would be in the minority.
Sadly, we lost our Cosmo, a 12-year old husky, five weeks ago. The house feels empty without her. When I get up in the morning or I walk into the house, I do not hear the patter of feet or hear her.

We are a nation of dog lovers, but right under our nose we know that dogs are being mistreated, abused, used and discarded. Yesterday, we heard horrendous stories of female dogs arriving into the care of Dogs Trust expecting a fifth or sixth litter, although they were barely puppies themselves. I cannot believe that somebody would allow a six-month old dog to go through that. It is absolutely horrendous. They were left with multiple scars from C-sections and some were so ill-treated that they were matted with their own faeces and they had to be sedated to be groomed and to enable them to give birth. Let us imagine the trauma that would have on the mother and the pups inside her. We would be horrified to think of that happening to our own dogs.

The Dog Breeding Establishments Act introduced in 2010 only makes it a legal requirement for any facility with six or more breeding dogs to be licensed through the local authority. There is no cap on the number of breeding dogs that a facility can have. That is just unbelievable. At the moment, legislation also states that the ratio of staff to dogs in kennels must be 1:25. That is one person for 25 adult dogs. If we multiply that by each dog having up to six puppies, that is 1:175, which is unimaginable.

Dog rescue facilities must be properly funded and resourced to cater for and continue to do the amazing work they do for dog welfare and highlighting the responsibilities that come with being a dog owner.

We must end the process of cruel breeding practices and so-called puppy farms. There must be an urgent review of the Dog Breeding Establishments Act and legislation and guidelines must be strengthened. The cruel practice of female dogs being reared as puppy machines is inhumane and must stop.

We support the intention of the Dog Welfare (Amendment) Bill. We believe that Deputy Whitmore's Bill will improve animal welfare standards for dogs and end some of the cruel practices that occur on these puppy farms.

Dog welfare should also be looked at on a cross-Border basis. We need to bring the whole island into line with best practice for our dogs because we cannot have a situation on the island of Ireland where there is more than one set of legislation, as bad practices will just move to the other side of the Border. We must ensure that we work on a cross-Border basis so that all dog welfare legislation is co-ordinated.

Having listened to the stories of Deputies Gould, Donnelly and Ward and their dogs I am reminded of the phrase, if you want a friend in politics, get a dog. Ireland is in the midst of a dog welfare crisis. That is not a phrase that I use lightly. Today, more than 3,000 dogs are in pounds and rescue centres across the country. Every week we hear of rescue centres overwhelmed, a foster network stretched to its limit, and of families heartbroken after discovering the hidden cruelty behind their family puppy due to an industry that has gone unchecked for far too long.

The facts speak for themselves. In 2022, more than 7,300 dogs entered Irish pounds, a staggering 77% increase from 2021. Despite the tireless work of staff and volunteers, 340 dogs were euthanised. It could have been prevented from ever reaching this point if our laws were fit for purpose. The shameful truth is that, as has been said, Ireland has become the puppy-farm capital of Europe. Up to 30,000 dogs are exported each year into illegal markets abroad. When we include unregistered backyard breeding, that figure may rise to 100,000 puppies bred in conditions that range from inadequate to outright cruel.

I very much welcome Deputy Whitmore's Bill, which shines a light on what has effectively become a profit-driven model of exploitation rooted in animal cruelty. We are talking about an industry worth over €200 million, one that, in some of its worst forms, is built on practices of cruelty that border on outright criminality. Yet, it is our animal welfare charities, operating on shoestring budgets, that are left to pick up the pieces. They are the ones dealing with the endless stream of neglected, sick and traumatised dogs. Countless animals are suffering the consequences of poor and irresponsible breeding, and far too many are being euthanised as a result.

In some of the large-scale breeding operations, there can be as many as 300 pregnant mothers at any one time. Females can be bred from as young as six months old and are forced to give birth again and again, with little regard for their health or well-being. The puppies themselves often come into the world deformed, sick, or burdened with long-term physical and behavioural issues. A puppy should be cared for, nurtured and held during the first crucial 12 weeks of life, not treated as a commodity to be produced for profit.

This simply cannot continue. We need stronger oversight, higher standards and meaningful enforcement. I welcome the opportunity for us to debate the Bill today. I hope it proceeds to Committee Stage. I was not present for the earlier part of the debate but I note the ministerial amendment. It is time for the Bill to move to Committee Stage. We do not need to wait for a year down the line.

As a result of weak regulation, harmful practices have been allowed to flourish. Under the current system puppies can be bred from females as young as four months old. Female dogs can be repeatedly bred, with almost no restrictions. Oversight is inconsistent, and enforcement is patchy at best. Backyard breeders continue to operate with virtually no accountability.

Local authorities do their best with the resources they have, but they cannot enforce what is, in reality, an unenforceable system. There is no dedicated Garda unit for animal cruelty. Many cases only come to light when neighbours, for instance, become concerned, meaning countless animals suffer unseen, behind closed doors.

Animal sanctuaries are at breaking point as unprecedented numbers of puppies, kittens and horses are abandoned and soaring costs and falling donations leave those charities struggling to cope. This situation is not sustainable. It is not humane, and it is not who we claim to be as a nation that values compassion, responsibility and community.

This Bill should have a face and a name. At this point I would like to talk about a small pup that I have spoken about before in this Chamber. It is a pup called Stout from my constituency of Wexford, who has reached thousands of people because of an online campaign. Stout suffered from severe health difficulties caused by malnutrition, poor breeding practices and the appalling, unsanitary conditions in which he was kept. Despite every effort by the Wexford SPCA, Stout lost his life last August. However, because two people, Tara O'Connor and Kevin Keegan, refused to let Stout's suffering be in vain, his legacy lives on. They have led a compassionate and determined campaign, rallying animal lovers across the county, the country and beyond, and called for legislation that holds breeders accountable and centres animal welfare in every aspect of dog breeding. They have a campaign called Stout's law, which proposes that we finally recognise dogs not merely as personal property, but as living beings with intrinsic needs, with the right to comfort, proper care, and the ability to express normal behaviour.

Deputy Whitmore's Bill offers a strong, structured and humane solution. I welcome this Bill in the Dáil today. My colleague, Deputy O'Donoghue, our spokesperson on agriculture, which animal welfare falls under, has also begun to process a Bill after hearing about Stout's law. He recommends a cap of 30 breeding females per site; minimum and maximum breeding ages; a limit of one litter per year and four in a lifetime; a staff-to-animal ratio of 10:1; a ban on surgical artificial insemination; and updated fees to reflect higher welfare standards. Additionally, the Bill includes criminal penalties for breaches - fines up to €250,000 and imprisonment of up to five years for serious offences.

These are not unreasonable demands. They are the minimum standards required for ethical breeding. We are calling for Stout's law to be incorporated into Deputy Whitmore's Bill. This would strengthen the legislation by establishing stricter limits on age and the duration and conditions of breeding; limiting lifetime litters; creating an independent regulator with real enforcement powers; supporting local authorities in oversight; outlawing backyard puppy farms once and for all; and ensuring transparency and accountability at every step. Stout's law would ensure that welfare is not an afterthought but the foundation. It would ensure breeders have a legal, moral and enforceable duty to provide freedom from discomfort, distress and neglect, and freedom to behave as dogs are meant to behave.

Rescue centres should not be forced to pick up the pieces of an industry that profits from suffering. They should not be dealing with litters born with degenerative conditions, malnourished mothers or traumatised animals that have known nothing but stress and confinement. We have a serious animal welfare problem in Ireland and we have a responsibility - morally, socially and legislatively - to confront it. By supporting this Bill and incorporating Stout's law within it, we can send a clear message: that Ireland no longer tolerates cruelty behind closed doors; that compassion must outweigh profit; and that the welfare of animals is a reflection on the values we hold as a society.

Stout did not survive but his legacy can ensure that thousands of other dogs do. It is time now to reform our laws, to strengthen enforcement, to protect vulnerable animals and give Ireland a dog-breeding system we can be proud of. I urge everybody in this Chamber to support the Dog Welfare (Amendment) Bill 2025 and formally incorporate Stout’s law into this legislation for Stout and for the countless dogs suffering and that will continue to suffer if we do not act upon this now.

Before I close, I want to highlight one more emerging concern. I spoke recently with the DSPCA about the worrying rise in kitten farming and the growing demand for fashionable breeds fuelled by viral trends on social media in creating large profit-driven breeding operations where appearance is prioritised over animal welfare. I have seen this myself on countless occasions on social media. Kitten farming may be less widely recognised than puppy farming but the suffering it causes is every bit as real. We must also get ahead of this issue before it becomes another real problem.
I earnestly request everyone to support Deputy Whitmore’s Bill.

It is really important that we be clear about the central question we are debating here and will vote on tonight. This is a law that seeks to reduce cruelty to dogs. It is important for the hundreds of thousands of dog owners and lovers in this country who know the innate sense of injustice and fury when they see or hear of a dog being mistreated. I have heard that sense from many of the Deputies who have contributed already today but it is important for those dog lovers to know that this Bill will be delayed tonight for 12 months. Law that would lessen cruelty to dogs in this country will be kicked down the road for a year. I want to thank Deputy Whitmore for bringing forward this important Bill and we in the Green Party will support it.

Commercial-scale dog breeding is not something I will pretend to have any regard for even with regulation in place. It is an industry that prioritises profit over welfare where profit is the product of how efficiently and at how large a scale litters of puppies can be bred and born. That is why Deputy Whitmore’s Bill is so welcome. It seeks to amend a piece of legislation that was introduced by my former colleague, John Gormley, when he was Minister in 2010, which was the first measure to attempt to regulate the factory-like breeding of dogs in Ireland. At that time, that particular law was strongly supported by animal welfare groups and by veterinary campaigners. Fifteen years on from that law, the measures being proposed in the Bill today are absolutely necessary to ensure we have an effective, humane regulatory system in place where dog breeding is taking place.

In particular, I welcome the proposed measures to regulate breeding practices that would address some of the physically extreme practices that can cause significant suffering for dogs, like a minimum age for breeding, like a maximum number of litters per year, like an annual breeding limit and a minimum age for separation. Perhaps most critically, it looks to outlaw the horrendous practice of surgical artificial insemination. I know this was something Deputy Quaide focused on in his contribution and it is an issue on which I have been raising parliamentary questions in recent months. Surgical artificial insemination is an issue that is long past time for action. The Veterinary Council of Ireland has already updated its code of practice to include a prohibition on canine surgical artificial insemination across all breeds, including greyhounds. It is banned in the UK and New Zealand. It is an absolutely unnecessary procedure that inflicts significant pain and creates a risk of infection to the dog to simply maximise litters and ultimately profit. It must be banned by statute and that ban must be enforced. Any breaches must carry strict penalties and that ban must include greyhounds as well.

Of course, what has always been remarkable to me is that when it comes to legislating for animal welfare in Ireland, it is the people who are firmly on the side of change. People in Ireland are shocked to hear about some of the practices that take place on animals in our own country. It has always been my experience that the vast majority of Irish people, rural and urban alike, want a humane regulatory system in place that seeks to put the welfare of animals at its heart but every time it comes to actually making even a small change, the political fight is entrenched. It is vitriolic. Those proposing changes are attacked and it is escalated into some sort of perverse city versus country culture war. That is done as a very deliberate tactic. I remember in 2010 when the Green Party introduced the puppy farming regulation Bill and a ban on stag hunting, the money and effort that were put into AstroTurfing a lobby was absolutely incredible. People should be in no doubt about the difficulty with which legislating to improve the lot of animals is resisted politically in this country. Again, what always amazes me is that opposition to change is coming from tiny, unrepresentative interest groups. Although they are unrepresentative, they are able to generate such noise that the larger parties bend to their will every single time. It is essential that this Bill, or an identical version from the Government, be passed during the lifetime of this Dáil. I do not accept the justification for a 12-month delay, and I will oppose that delay tonight, but in 12 months' time when the Bill does advance, the Green Party and I look forward to supporting Deputy Whitmore in advancing it and seeing it passed.

I welcome and support this Dog Welfare (Amendment) Bill 2025. I thank the Social Democrats for bringing this forward. We need to stop cruelty to dogs and there is no doubt that the area of dog welfare needs to be more formally regulated, especially in the area of dog breeding establishments like puppy farms. In August 2023, the then Department of Rural and Community Development released statistics that showed that 7,352 dogs entered Irish pounds. That was a massive 77% increase over 2021. Twice as many dogs were euthanised in 2022 over 2021. The Dogs Trust recorded the highest number of surrender requests - 3,968 - since it opened in 2009. The number of dogs rescued by the Irish Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals rose by 47% last year over 2022. Staffing, or more correctly the lack of staffing, is a significant issue in these establishments. Our poor, almost non-existent regulatory system has resulted in a €200 million industry and this country becoming the puppy farm capital of Europe, exporting a significant number of puppies to more regulated countries.

Apart from welfare issues, other concerns include tax avoidance, environmental concerns, disease spread and fraudulent practices. The Bill is a reasonable, common sense and fair attempt to properly regulate these dog breeding establishments.

An issue that does not appear to be covered in the Bill and is not implemented under current legislation is the whole area of enforcement. There is little point in having legislation and regulations if they are not being enforced. We recall the light-touch regulation in the building industry over the years. There is effectively no enforcement of current licensing or microchipping regulations. There is a complete under-resourcing in this area with little or no staff or infrastructure including pounds. This is resulting in a large-scale cohort of unlicensed and unmicrochipped dogs. These dogs often run in packs and are a danger to the public, especially children and the elderly. Of course, it also involves a lot of significant income to local authorities. Immediate and significant steps must be taken to address this issue and it is an area that should be included in this legislation as it proceeds through the Oireachtas.

The current dog breeding situation is not humane. It is effectively cruelty behind closed doors. The Government's response to the Bill is to kick it down the road for at least another year and probably for an awful lot longer. This is not good enough. I ask the Minister of State to reconsider this unacceptable response.

We have a large majority of dog breeders who do their work well and do it right. They are legislated for and they have regular visits from vets and regular welfare visits and they do everything correctly. We have a minority who are not doing it right. Any minority that is not doing it right deserves the heavy hand of the law. The Bill needs to be right once and for all but the biggest issue with introducing any Bill in the House is enforcement. The last Bill on this matter brought to the House was in 2012 and it has never been enforced properly. The resources for enforcing animal welfare have never been provided.

I come from an area of greyhound breeding, greyhound racing, horse racing and everything. I come from a family where my parents had respect and said dogs had to be walked and fed and that the welfare of the dog was to be looked after. I will stick with greyhounds. In the Banogue and Croom area, Moloney's have a place where dogs are brought after racing to be rehomed. It is an amazing place to visit where everything is done properly. Have I seen places where people are doing wrong? Yes, I have. Have I raised issues with this? Yes, I have.

People treating the welfare of their animals correctly and looking after dogs as if they were one of their own also need to see an incentive for doing things right. The biggest issue I see with animal welfare is enforcement. Nobody wants to see an animal being mistreated. The biggest issue with welfare is to make sure all the laws are implemented and things are done properly for the welfare of the animal. This is what we need to do. The biggest thing is to give resources for enforcement. We can make all the laws in the world but if we do not enforce them, things do not happen.

I welcome the Bill from the Social Democrats. I support and welcome the Dog Welfare (Amendment) Bill and I support its core objectives, which I believe are to regulate the industry, improve standards in the industry and enhance public safety. There are good breeders in the country doing good work. Equally, there are some horrendous practices happening in the country. Therefore, it is only right that we seek to introduce a minimum standard. The Bill is important in terms of introducing vital protections, limits to breeding frequency, which is very important, and minimum standards for the care of dogs. Preventing overbreeding, age limits for female dogs, a minimum age of pups for separation and staff ratios are all really important.

The lack of regulation and enforcement in this area is causing major difficulty for shelters right across the country. There are over 7,000 dogs in shelters in Ireland. Many of them are pedigree dogs and many have come from the breeding sector. This is quite incredible. The number of dogs euthanised in the country is increasing, and it has increased by 10% over the past year. I thank the shelters throughout the country. In my constituency, Mayo SPCA in Ballyhaunis is run by Ms Marian Biesty, a wonderful woman, and a team of volunteers. They do tremendous work. I have visited it many times. Ms Biesty won Mayo person of the year recently and it was very well deserved. North West SPCA in Ballina is also doing great work, as is the Mayo dog pound in Castlebar. This Bill would relieve some of the challenges and pressures these dog shelters face. I urge the Minister of State to prioritise this and to work with those on this side of the House to make sure that minimum standards in the industry are addressed.

I want to raise the issue of sheep worrying around the country, in particular on the sheep plains in south Mayo. Some of the best sheep farmers are in south Mayo and in parts of north Mayo also. They are being terrorised by groups of individuals coming onto their lands and sheep worrying. I attended a meeting recently where I spoke to a young farmer who lost half his pedigree stock overnight. Several were savaged by dogs and others were caught in ditches, drains and rivers on the farm. The Bill would assist with this. I am particularly keen to ensure we have a system whereby the microchipping of all of these dogs and enforcement happens.

In Mayo, there are only three dog wardens. It is an enormous county. There are very many occasions at weekends and evenings when no dog warden is on duty. Then gardaí are called but are simply not equipped to deal with it. Gardaí do not even have scanners to scan these dogs. This is how poorly equipped we are in the country to deal with this. The Bill will assist with this but there are significant steps we need to take on sheep worrying, microchipping and ensuring gardaí have the ability to protect farmers.

I am a strong advocate for preserving Ireland's rural heritage. In the Dáil, I have spoken about the cultural importance of local greyhound racing and traditions that bring communities together. I have also called for the continued State support of €19 million annually for greyhound tracks to ensure these venues can survive and thrive. I believe in sustaining rural life, protecting jobs and celebrating the traditions that make our countryside unique.

As we approach Christmas, it is important to remember that bringing a puppy into your home is a lifelong commitment and not a seasonal impulse. Leading organisations across Ireland have issued strong warnings about buying dogs from breeders during the festive period. The ISPCA has highlighted that puppy farmers exploit the Christmas rush, producing litters in poor conditions without proper care, vaccination or microchipping. They urge families to delay purchase until after the holidays and to consider adoption from registered rescues instead. The DSPCA, speaking on RTÉ, warned about heavily discounted puppies being sold for as little as €100. Many of these dogs lack vital vaccinations and are at risk of serious illness, such as parvovirus. Its advice is clear, and it is that if people do buy, they should have the puppy examined by a vet within 24 hours and check all health records.

Aside from being our best friends, dogs are an integral part of many families, especially for those with autistic children or blind persons, yet families in Ireland hoping for an autism assistance dog face long waits. Leading providers, such as My Canine Companion and Irish Guide Dogs for the Blind, have closed their waiting lists until early 2026, reflecting huge demand. Autism Assistance Dogs Ireland recently reopened applications but the process from assessment to placement can take one to two years. These dogs transform lives, offering safety and independence, but planning ahead and engaging early is essential.

Dog behaviourists remind us that Christmas is the worst time to get a puppy. The chaos of the season makes training and bonding difficult, and responsible breeders typically avoid selling at this time.

This Christmas, let us put welfare first by avoiding impulse buys and steering clear of puppy farms. If someone is ready for a dog, they should choose a reputable source or give a rescue dog the gift of a loving home. We all know the saying that a puppy is for life, not just for Christmas. I pay tribute to people who look after dogs. In Church Cross in west Cork, the Collins family look after retired greyhounds. The incredible care they give to their dogs needs to be commended and I commend them. I have been there with them and I would nearly be encouraged to stay and sleep in one of the dog beds because it is such a beautiful layout. They give the dogs great attention and care. The dogs are well fed and have warm kennels.
However, there is a huge issue of dogs killing sheep in rural Ireland, including in my constituency, and that needs to be addressed as well.

I am delighted to be able to speak today on a cause that is very close to my heart. My family and I have always had dogs. My current girl, Jenko, is a rescue, and I applaud all of those who work and volunteer in dog shelters and rescues for their commitment, passion and deep care. Most of those who provide day care, kennels and breed dogs have their dogs' welfare as their number one priority. Dogs are not only part of our families but they work with and alongside us, too. For example, I have worked with and supported Irish Guide Dogs for the Blind all my life. The partnership and bond between person and dog I have seen brings out the best in our humanity. Working with dogs makes us better people and there is no greater gift that a dog can give.

Since being elected to this House a little over 12 months ago, and as a long-time advocate for dog welfare, I have raised numerous areas where reform is necessary. I have called for: a single, centralised dog microchipping register; a distinct tax code for dog breeders; regulation for online sales, and increased sanctions for dog breeding and welfare violations. This is not just a matter of dog health and welfare, but also consumer protection and public safety, as poorly bred and poorly socialised dogs are more likely to exhibit antisocial and aggressive behaviour. Fine Gael has always stood for strong animal welfare protections. Recent developments include how the State now funds over 100 animal welfare organisations, with funding increasing from €2 million in 2020 to over €6 million today. We have established a new and independently chaired advisory council on companion animal welfare and there have been improvements in dog control, with additional funding for dog wardens in all local authorities.

In my constituency of Dublin Rathdown, we now have three dog wardens covering the area where previously there was just one. I know the Minister, Deputy Heydon, is fully committed to continuing improvements in this area, and I have been working with him to deliver progress. As we are all aware, planning for the updated animal welfare strategy 2026 to 2030 is under way. In support of this, I joined the Minister on November 19 to launch a six-week public consultation process. This will seek public views, which will inform the strategy. I encourage all of those listening to this debate to contribute to the consultation.

Specifically on dog welfare control and breeding, the dog control and breeding stakeholder group, established by Fine Gael during the last Government, is expected to provide its final report and recommendations in early 2026. At EU level, the first ever EU-wide minimum standards to address puppy farms and illegal imports is near final agreement. We need to allow time for these processes, which are near completion, to be completed. Capturing the range of stakeholder, expert and wider public views with the new EU-wide minimum standards will form the basis for an updated animal welfare strategy, which will be published in 2026. Taking this time matters for improving the health and welfare of dogs. Taking this time will improve public safety and public confidence that dogs in our communities are well raised and cared for.

This Bill today is actually premature, and really is just an example of where the Social Democrats are again exploiting a vulnerable group, in this case a group that cannot even speak for themselves, although my own dog, Jenko, is actually incredibly vocal and would probably have something to say on this.
Jesus.
She is talking so much rubbish.
I look forward to the outcomes of the process I have outlined and to working positively with the Minister to deliver positively for dogs, their families and our wider communities.

speech.from: Minister of State at the Department of Culture, Communications and Sport (Deputy Charlie McConalogue)
speech.p: On behalf of the Minister for agriculture and the Minister of State, Deputy Grealish, I thank Deputy Whitmore for bringing forward this Bill and for her many contributions in relation to it.

The Department has committed to making a difference around dog control, breeding and welfare. The Minister also wishes to emphasise that this timed amendment, as put forward, is focused on providing sufficient time to allow for existing processes that have been in train for some time to come to fruition. This is also about ensuring that there is sufficient public, stakeholder and expert engagement in the area of dog control, breeding and welfare-enacting legislation prior to any legislative change. The Minister is looking forward to engaging proactively with all interested stakeholders and contributors such as the initiator of the Bill, Deputy Whitmore, on the output of the recommendations emanating from the process. The Minister is very happy to consider the need for legislative change in this space and engage proactively with all interested parties in the context of the completion of the evidence-based and stakeholder-driven processes that are in place to inform these considerations by the Minister and the Department.

I know there has been a very significant and comprehensive debate this morning on an issue that is particularly important and for which the Deputy has been a long-time advocate. The Department and the Minister are committed to engaging further, with a view to implementing changes in due course.

I think the lack of seriousness of the Minister of State's response was incredible. I have to say it was quite shocking. He did not even take any significant amount of his allocated time for the response. I am a cat owner, not a dog owner, but I know that many of my fellow cat owners will be very supportive. I was sitting this morning with my cat, listening to Deputy Whitmore on "Morning Ireland", and the cat meowed at me. I think she meowed in approval, though I am not quite sure. I am here anyway supporting this and I want to congratulate Deputy Whitmore for the incredible work she has done and the leadership she has shown on this.

Of course, dogs are central to our lives today. They also central to Irish mythology, our language and our history. There are some lovely seanfhocail, drawing on dogs, which give wisdom on life in general. One for example is, "Is dána gach madra in ndoras a thí féin", which means "every dog is daring on his own doorstep". Another one is, "Ag cur madraí i bhfuinneoga", which means "putting dogs in windows", which actually is a phrase to describe attempts to distract people. This is a good description of the Government and a lot of its housing policy.

More broadly on this, I want to talk about the ongoing issues of animal cruelty that happen and which this Bill addresses. Dogs are part of our families. The idea that dogs and other animals are somehow separate from humans is something that a lot of people are trying to challenge. Many see this separation between us when there is none. They are part of us. We are all living beings on this planet together and of course we should be living together, but there is so much horrific cruelty.

I want to flag the issue of housing and the situation whereby we are now seeing mass evictions. Many people are being forced out of their homes and are then having to get rid of their pets because they cannot be taken into emergency accommodation. On top of the trauma of losing their home, families and, in particular, children are going through the trauma of losing their pets because this Government has completely failed to ensure people have a home and to prevent them from being evicted. On top of that, we still have a disgraceful situation whereby most private rental accommodation does not allow people to have pets. Representatives from Dogs Trust say that one of the main reasons people contact them is because they have to move to a rental home where pets are not allowed. They have to go through the heartbreak of surrendering their family pets. As well as explaining to their children that they have to leave their home, they also have to explain why part of the family - the pets - cannot come with them. This month, I was in touch with a woman who was facing the direct trauma of homelessness. She had been trying day and night to find a home for herself but was not able to do so.
They lost their home and they also lost their pets. This needs to be addressed too.

As a new TD, I find it deeply frustrating that Government Ministers say to us constantly that the Social Democrats have no solutions, policies or ideas and then, when we come to the Dáil with solutions, policies and ideas, they are dismissed and rejected. In his opening speech the Minister of State asked us to accept his bona fides about the 12-month delay. I would accept that if this did not happen every single time we put forward legislation. It happened the last time with our Bill to reduce the voting age to sixteen and it happened to our Bill in the Seanad. Time and again, the Government kicks the can down the road and dismisses our ideas.

The Minister of State, Deputy McConalogue, said we had a comprehensive debate. It is remarkable how few Members of Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael were here to discuss the Bill. One Member from each of those two parties showed up. It was not a comprehensive debate and there was not meaningful engagement with the Government. That is disappointing. These are important issues. We should be progressing this legislation, taking it to Committee Stage, going through the detail and passing it. The response from the Government is disappointing.

I thank my colleague Deputy Whitmore for bringing forward the legislation and putting forward these proposals and ideas. I also thank Dog Law Ireland which worked with her on the Bill. In essence, the Bill would regulate breeding practices and outlaw harmful procedures that cause unnecessary suffering to dogs. At the moment, there are no protections for dogs in breeding establishments. We cannot let dogs throughout the country suffer because successive governments have failed to prioritise animal welfare.

I strongly believe that improving animal welfare should have cross-party support in the House. Dog breeding in this country has been likened to the fast fashion market, with any breed of puppy readily available at the click of a button. Sadly, too many people remain unaware of the ethical concerns associated with this. Our poorly regulated framework has created a multimillion euro industry and resulted in Ireland becoming a huge exporter of puppies to more tightly regulated countries. It has also allowed incredibly harmful practices of surgical artificial insemination to remain legal.

The current lack of regulation has created a system in which dog rescues simply cannot keep up with the pace at which dog breeders are breeding. Nor can they cope with ever-increasing surrender requests or dog abandonment rates. Right now in my city, the Cork Dog Action Welfare group has more than 100 dogs in foster homes and shelters. On the website of the Cork Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals today, one of the first dogs listed for adoption is Ila, who the CSPCA describes as having started life on a puppy farm but is now free from that fate. I commend those organisations and the volunteers who do fantastic work.
I urge Members across the House to support this Bill. They should remember the dogs we have talked about today and put better regulations in place for them.

I thank everybody who contributed today. It is clear that this Bill is supported by most Members of the House. Most people can understand the need for it and the urgency with it. That is why, when the Minister of State spoke initially about a 12-month delay, I was concerned because that would mean that, over those 12 months, another 100,000 pups will be born in Ireland, many of them in horrific conditions. I understand the need to go through processes and I know a number of consultations are taking place. It is really important that the voices of dog rescues, vets and those involved in looking after dogs are heard. I understand the need for those processes but I want the timeframe to be expedited.

I thank the Minister of State because I have just received notification from him that he is prepared to move to a nine-month timeframe, which would be sufficient to get through those consultations. I am really pleased with that and the Social Democrats will accept it. We want to work closely with the Government on this issue, which we are passionate about. It is important, on issues like this, that the Social Democrats work constructively with the Government. People want to see action on this issue, regardless of which party they support. Whether it is the Social Democrats, Fianna Fáil, Fine Gael or Independents or whoever else, it does not matter because people want to see this actioned.

I thank the Minister of State for his confirmation that a nine-month timeframe will be set on the Bill and that he will work closely with me and my party. I have some other suggestions. I think it would be appropriate at this stage to see if additional funding can be provided for rescues that are dealing with what is a crisis at the moment and to examine the possibility of establishing a special committee to get this Bill across the line as soon as possible.

I thank the Minister of State very much for the change and I look forward to working with him. I hope to hear from him, the Minister, Deputy Heydon, and indeed the Department shortly about next steps on how we can progress this Bill.
We may need to suspend for five minutes while we get clarity because a new amendment would be required and we do not currently have one in front of us.
The delay would be for nine months.
The current amendment provides for 12 months. We will suspend briefly to get clarity and make sure the procedure is correct.

speech.p: Is it agreed, by leave of the House, to amend the Government's amendment to substitute "nine months" for "12 months"? Agreed. In that case, I will now put the question on the amended amendment.

debateSection.summary: Question, "That the Government amendment, as amended, be agreed to", put and agreed to.

debateSection.name: questions
debateSection.heading: Ceisteanna ó Cheannairí - Leaders' Questions

speech.p: Tá fearg mhór ann go mbeidh ar dhaoine leochaileacha íoc as pacáistí táibléad blister mar gheall ar chinneadh an Rialtais. Beidh tionchar ar leith aige seo ar dhaoine atá ag dul siar i mblianta agus ar dhaoine atá ag maireachtáil le néaltrú agus galar Alzheimer a bhraitheann ar na pacáistí seo. Tá a fhios againn nach bhfuil sé seo ceart. Caithfidh an Rialtas gníomhú chun a chinntiú go leanfaidh na daoine seo a bheith ábalta a gcuid pacáistí táibléad blister a fháil saor in aisce.

The Taoiseach's Government's decision to restrict medications covered under the phased dispensing scheme operated by pharmacies is a disaster. The Government's decision means some of the most vulnerable people will no longer receive tablet blister packs free of charge. We are talking of tens of thousands of older people living with conditions such as dementia and Alzheimer's. They rely on tablet blister packs to help manage their medication. We are also talking about people with disabilities who are under real pressure with the cost of living. The packs help them make sure they take the right dosage at the right time of day. The Government's decision means the cost of dispensing the blister packs - paid for by the State for decades - will now be passed on to these vulnerable customers. They will be hit by fee charges of up to €50 a month in some cases for these packs.

This is a bad decision for the Government at any time but it made this cruel choice during a cost-of-living crisis when every euro is precious to people. It is like it cannot stop itself from making life harder for people. It hiked up student fees, the local property tax and the cost of petrol and diesel. It stands back and allows big energy companies to jack up electricity and gas bills and now it hits the most vulnerable elderly people. It is putting huge stress on people during the Christmas period as they know they are going to have to face these charges come 1 January.

My phone, and I am sure those of others as well, has been hopping with people very worried and very angry over this. I spoke to one elderly man this morning. He is in his late 70s and told me his lovely wife suffers from dementia. He said without the blister pack he would find it very hard to manage her medication but he does not know where they are going to find the extra money to pay for them. He says they are literally down to the last euro every couple of weeks as it is.

The explanation the Taoiseach and his Government have offered is the State never agreed to pay for the dispensing of these blister packs in the first place. Does he really think that matters to people who rely on them? The fact is the government has been paying for these for decades. If there was a mistake in how the packs were being paid for and a correction had to be made, it should have been made to ensure those folks could continue receiving their tablet blister packs as they have been but, no, the Government decided to punish vulnerable people, to ratchet up their costs instead of making sure they are looked after. The truth is the Government had a chance to sort this out. Back in October when it was finalising the new community pharmacy agreement we in Sinn Féin warned it was a big mistake to exclude the blister packs, but the Government chose to ignore that warning, chose to push on and now elderly people and others are paying the price. It is not right, it is not fair and it needs to be stopped.

I have simple questions. On behalf of the man I was talking to, and I am sure many others right across this State, I ask the Taoiseach whether he thinks it is right that people with dementia, Alzheimer's and other conditions who received their blister packs free of charge up until now will have to pay for them on 1 January. Will the Government reverse this terrible decision and ensure vulnerable people can continue getting their blister packs free of charge?

First of all, tá an-chuid déanta i gcoitinne ag an Rialtas chun costais a bhaineann le cúrsaí leighis a ísliú. Tá sé sin déanta againn, go háirithe ó thaobh an drugs payment scheme. Tá an tairseach i bhfad níos fearr anois ná mar a bhí sé cúpla bliain ó shin. More generally on the cost of medicine, and particularly charges and so on, this Government has, over the last number of years, significantly reduced the cost of accessing medicine. The DPS threshold in particular has come significantly down, exceeding even commitments made in various manifestoes and so forth. That needs to be acknowledged, as does the abolition of charges in hospitals and so on, so without question right across the board we have reduced costs in the healthcare area. It is without question and the Deputy just cannot get away with saying we are wilfully increasing costs all over the place as he just did. We are not. If you look over the last number of years, costs have come down in terms of State charges in respect of hospitals - acute hospitals, emergency departments - and in respect of medicine and the cost of medicine, particularly the DPS threshold and other bespoke interventions also.

More generally on cost-of-living measures, in the budget we took measures to support families who are on low incomes in particular. The ESRI's evaluation of the budget bears that out in that the two lowest deciles gained the most in respect of the budgetary allocation. Also, if you look at real wages and incomes, they are growing at approximately 3% per annum this year and we have targeted measures effectively on the cost-of-living side to support those most in need.

On phased dispensing, we will certainly look at any situation where there is potential hardship on any patient or any person in receipt of medicine, but we have to be clear-eyed as well. The Deputy mentioned pharmacies and so on. There is an issue between the HSE and pharmacies in respect of the whole area of phased dispensing, which was introduced as far back as 1996 for patient safety reasons. The supply of medication in instalments can support patients prescribed certain high-risk medications who would be at risk of medication misadventure if these medications were supplied monthly. Where a phased dispensing claim is submitted the current requirement is an item must be dispensed in the pharmacy across multiple supply occasions. Community pharmacies receive additional payments for phased dispensing. Monitored dosing systems, sometimes referred to as blister packs or compliance aids, are systems that enable the individual medicine doses to be organised according to the prescribed dose schedule. The HSE's contention is that monitored dosing systems and phased dispensing are two separate processes and that phased dispensing requires the patient to present to the pharmacy on multiple occasions in the month each week, as it would be unsafe for the patient to have the totality of their medication in one supply occasion. Monitored dosing systems are ordinarily provided in one visit and packaged to indicate when a medication should be taken. The State had never agreed to monitored dosing systems and that was the context-----
That is not the question.

I am sorry, this is the issue. Invariably Sinn Féin will come in another day and question Government about how the costs got out of control, value for money and so on. There has to be an engagement between the pharmacy sector and the HSE on these matters. Unfortunately in the Oireachtas from time to time, the Deputies opposite just blow all that out of the water and do not even allow interrogation of the issues. Government will interrogate this again with the HSE and others-----
Talking down the clock.
-----but there are issues here. I mean, there are agreements between-----
Three seconds.
-----the Irish Pharmacy Union-----
Two, one. Suigh síos.
-----and the Department-----
Thank you, Taoiseach. Deputy Doherty to respond.
The National Centre for Pharmacoeconomics carried out an evidence assessment.
Thank you, Taoiseach.
I am just giving the background as the question was asked. It indicated the evidence was very equivocal in terms of supporting the programme. We will go back and discuss this with the HSE.
Deputy Doherty to respond.
During discussions with the pharmacy union-----
Thank you, Taoiseach. The time is up. Deputy Doherty to respond.
-----it was agreed that improved controls would be introduced.

I asked the Taoiseach the question and he did not answer it. I asked him the question, with respect, of whether he believes people with dementia and Alzheimer's who were receiving the blister packs free of charge should be charged for them from 1 January. No matter what way the Taoiseach presents it, these packs were being funded. For right or wrong, they were being funded. Of course there are issues. The issue is that the man who was talking to me this morning and his wife who is suffering with dementia will have to pay in January for the blister pack they were getting free of charge. Do not try to pull this one - that the Government is actually reducing the cost of medication - when people out there have been getting letters from their pharmacies saying from 1 January the HSE will no longer be providing blister packs and there will be an additional charge of €20 per month for the packs.

Please do not tell people that black is white and white is black. People know what is happening out there. The question is whether the Government is going to reverse this. These are elderly people and vulnerable people who rely on blister packs to ensure they take their medication on time. Many people cannot afford to pay for them.
The time is up. The Deputy’s point is made. I call the Taoiseach to respond.

It was a Government decision that restricted the way in which pharmacies were claiming, and it has resulted in this. Will the Taoiseach please answer the question? Will he reverse the decision? Should people with dementia and Alzheimer's, who were getting it free, have to pay for it in January?
My view on monitored dosing systems is that I am not sure there should be a fee attached to them at all, but I am not so sure either-----
What does that mean?

Hold on. I am not sure either that the State should be ponying up for everything here. There is no analysis by Deputy Doherty of both sides of this engagement. That is my point. There is too much of that in the House. The easy thing to go for is that the Government must pay for everything, no matter how it is presented or manifested. Deputy Doherty, even though he is finance spokesman, just casts aside any sense of controls whatsoever – “just let it rip” is his approach.

We want to look after people with Alzheimer's and dementia, and we have done in this Government. We have done far more in the last number of years for dementia patients than was done in the previous decade or more. That is a fact.
You put up the cost.
The Minister of State, Deputy Butler, was responsible for a lot of the very proactive work in respect of dementia.
The Taoiseach has just ten seconds left. What is he going to do?

There needs to be an engagement between the Irish Pharmacy Union and the HSE on this, but it cannot be the case that every new system or modification of a system or approach is just agreed. That cannot be it either.
The Government has just agreed a deal but it left out blister packs.

Yesterday, we saw the announcement from the Minister, Deputy Norma Foley, that the Government will replace the existing assessment of need process with a new system. However, I have deep concerns about the proposal announced to replace the requirement for a formal diagnosis when determining access to a special class or special school. As a former teacher, I cannot overstate the seriousness of this development. This proposal has profound implications for schools, teachers and the children and families who rely on appropriate, timely and specialist assessment. Replacing diagnostic criteria with an educational assessment places an unreasonable and unsafe burden on schools. To me, it seems that we will streamline the process of receiving therapies, but leave a massive void in how special classes and places will be assigned.

The Minister, Deputy Foley, reiterated yesterday that people will no longer need an assessment of need to get a place in a special school or class, instead saying it is up to education to decide on how these places will be assigned. She outlined that some sort of special educational assessment will be established to get a school place for a child, saying it was her hope that the Department of education would have the new system in place for the September 2027 academic year. Who will carry out this new special educational assessment? Will it be teachers or SENOs? There is no point in the Government suggesting that more psychologists, clinicians or multidisciplinary teams will be required, because the Government has made that money available to hire for these roles, but the roles are not being filled.

I also ask whether the Minister, Deputy Naughton, was aware of these changes yesterday, or was it a surprise to her? It was duly noted that there was no representative from the Department of education at this announcement yesterday. Teachers themselves will say that they are not the ones who should be in the position of determining an appropriate place for a child with additional needs. In reality, this leaves parents in a worse-off position. They will now be chasing two parallel pathways, one to get the therapies they need, and one to get the diagnosis and school place they need.

Does the Taoiseach believe that this makes sense? Yesterday, 85% of the teachers surveyed reported moderate to high work-related burnout. Is the Government now placing this burden on them? Teachers cannot and should not be expected to take on duties that belong to psychologists, clinicians or multidisciplinary teams. This shift undermines the integrity of the entire assessment process and places schools in an impossible position. It also risks leaving families unsupported and pupils at genuine risk of not receiving the appropriate provision that they are entitled to. The proposal seems to be driven not by what is best for children, but by the inability of the health and disability sector to manage the assessment of need backlog.

Who will carry out these educational assessments? How will the Department of education manage and resource this responsibility? Crucially, and I want an answer to this question, has the process of establishing this new special educational assessment begun within the Department of education?

First, I reject completely the assertions made by the Deputy in respect of this. I think he is missing the fundamental point. The assessment of need framework as it currently stands is not fit for purpose, and recent High Court decisions have made it less fit for purpose. The objective of the legislation, along with a whole series of other measures, is to prioritise and increase timely access to therapies for children. That is the fundamental point: to free up therapists in providing services and treatment.

The Department of education was intimately involved with the Department of children and other Departments under the Cabinet subcommittee on disability regarding this legislative change. We made a very clear decision early on in this Government that we were going to do this, and grasp the nettle in respect of it. We can go on here for another two years, with people coming in and complaining about this list and that waiting list, and they will keep on doing that - it is great stuff, wonderful - as the lists keep going up. The system is completely not fit for purpose. We want to utilise therapists to provide services to children, and we are going to do it.

Bottom-line legislation is the first step, but there is a whole series of other measures that we are taking as well. That basically means we are creating statutory guidelines to support assessment officers in making earlier determinations of disability, reducing the need for unnecessary or repeated clinical assessments. There will be proportionate assessments based on each child's circumstances, including the use of existing diagnostic information or reports, allowing for streamlined, desk-based reviews, where appropriate; and faster delivery of assessment reports provided at the earliest possible point, without affecting anyone's right to an assessment of need and without changing the statutory timeframes set out in the Act itself.

We will be doing a wider review of the Disability Act in early 2026 to ensure it reflects modern, rights-based child and adult-focused supports. A dedicated autism diagnostic assessment panel will be established. There will be a new autism assessment and intervention pathways protocol from 5 February 2026, ensuring consistent practice across primary care, CAMHS and CDNTs, and removing the requirement for an assessment of need to access non-health supports, such as special classes and school places. We do not want children waiting to get into a special class or a school place where the need is obvious. We do not want delays. We want to get the child access to facilities and therapies immediately.

There will be 11 new in-reach teams, with four staff in each team, to provide expert clinical guidance to the assessment staff. A new single point of access model from 2026 is being established - Bernard of Gloster and the HSE have led out on this - giving families one consistent entry route to primary care, CAMHS or the children's disability network teams.

The Deputy knows that we are rolling out the education therapy service in 45 special schools from the new year, and then, for the 2026-27 academic year, all special schools will have an education therapy service.
The time is up. I call Deputy Kenny.
The private procurement of assessment of need will be supported by €20 million in this year's budget, and there is more on top of that, but I do not have time to elaborate on it.

The question was simple. Who will carry out these educational assessments? Will it be teachers? Will it be SENOs? Who will it be? John Boyle from the INTO said this morning that teachers were not consulted, briefed or even informed in advance of these proposals. It is grossly unfair that Government Departments are using vulnerable children as political footballs after failing to provide them with timely assessments and therapeutic supports. The question is fairly simple. Who will carry out these educational assessments that were announced yesterday? I never said that I was against what was announced yesterday.
You did.
I never said that. What I asked was who will carry out these educational assessments. That was quite clear. The Taoiseach did not answer that question.
I did.

The question is fundamentally clear. Will the Department of education have this programme established by October next year? Right now, to me, it seems that it will not. The Government cannot even answer as to who will carry out these educational assessments. That is the question I am asking. Will it be teachers? Will it be SENOs? Who will it be?
Again, you did criticise it, by the way.
I did not, not once.
From the outset, you have been extremely negative. The whole question was articulated in a negative way.
That is not true.
That is your reality, Taoiseach.

Fine. I welcome Deputy Kenny's turnaround and reverse within five minutes. As for the question, I did say that there will be assessment teams. Teachers will not be assessing. I would appreciate, if the INTO has issues, that it would engage with us and engage with the Department of education. Do not be shooting from the hip.
Who will do the assessments?

People should not be shooting from the hip all the time. The current system is not fit for purpose. Many children will present with special needs from the earliest diagnosis, when it is very clear they have special needs. They do not need to go through elaborate further assessments of need before being allocated a school place.

We do need to streamline this. Therapists need to be freed up to provide services, to engage. That is what we want here, not endless long lists of people stuck for six or 12 months. We have to do this. No matter what political perspective one holds the system has to be unblocked.

Yesterday, the High Court heard details of a deeply disturbing case of child abuse. A 13-year-old boy who abused his six-year-old sister was given a tablet at the age of five. There was no parental controls on the device and he had totally unsupervised access to the Internet. By the age of just six he was viewing pornography for hours every day. This boy ultimately uploaded child abuse images of his sister online, prompting his arrest. Sentencing the boy, Ms Justice Mary Ellen Ring likened unchecked Internet access to children playing with matches.

Details of that shocking case were being heard as Australia introduced its social media ban for children under 16. It is a world first and we will all certainly be watching with huge interest to see how it progresses. However, I have a number of concerns about that kind of ban. For a start, most social media companies already have an age limit of 13 and we all know that just its not being enforced. Raising the age limit to 16 will similarly be easy to evade with teenagers creating fake accounts using virtual private networks, VPNs. Crucially, delaying access to social media sites does nothing about the recommender algorithms that are feeding children toxic content. We now have mountains of evidence about the threats posed by these algorithms. One study found teenage boys were being "bombarded" with misogynistic content within minutes of signing up to TikTok. Another study found 13-year-old users being shown videos about self harm and suicide within 20 minutes of setting up accounts. Social media platforms now routinely show graphic, violent or racist videos to people who are not looking for that content. This is not just having a hugely damaging impact on children but it is massively corrosive for society. It is spreading misinformation and hate through communities like wildfire.

I will be the first to acknowledge this is a hugely complex issue and there are no easy solutions. In know the Minister is currently looking at age verification for social media users. While I think that is part of the solution, it amounts to putting a sticking plaster on a gaping wound. There are also huge privacy concerns about mandating something like a digital wallet to access services online.

Each of us in this House knows we have to do more to protect children online. We know the current system is failing them. An obvious first step is to regulate the algorithms that boost extremist content to huge audiences online. By default, those systems should be off. Does the Taoiseach agree and will the Government act on this?

I thank the Deputy for raising what is a very important issue. The Government is talking a whole-of-society and a whole-of-government approach to online safety, recognising the rapid pace of change in the digital world and also the need for very co-ordinated, robust and rights-respecting responses. That response spans regulation, education, parental supports, age verification measures, curriculum reforms and school-level policies.

I am aware of that case yesterday and I heard reports in the media in relation to it. It does illustrate the enormous challenge and dangers here. Overall, we have to, through our education system, create a culture of strong self esteem and self respect among children from the earliest of ages. We have had to do this in the past to varying degrees in respect of other issues, be it drug addiction, alcohol addiction and so on. The most fundamental way of assisting society to cope is through very good policies at an early age and programmes from a psychological level which increase the self esteem of children to withstand and be resilient in the face of whatever comes at them in life subsequently. Of course, we can do much more than that.

Curricular reform is happening. There are school level policies and so on. The Minister, Deputy O'Donovan, with Coimisiún na Meán, now have stronger powers. There are obligations around harmful content. Stronger age verification for adult material is very important and risk mitigation requirements are designed to protect children.

At EU level, we are engaging. The digital age of majority must be considered across all member states to ensure harmonised protections under the Digital Services Act. We are also developing a secure privacy-focused approach to age verification and we are working to include age verification functionality in Ireland's digital wallet under the EU eIDAS project. That is about giving parents and young people a robust Government-backed mechanism to protect privacy. A large-scale pilot is planned for early next year.

We are strengthening digital well-being and online safety supports in schools. We have updated our child protection procedures. There is a lot happening in education, to be fair. There is a digital strategy for schools up to 2027. Oide technology in education provides professional learning for teachers and Webwise continues to lead on national awareness training, classroom resources on cyberbullying, image sharing, social media and emerging online risks. We have also acted to reduce mobile phone distraction and support student well-being during school day. We have introduced the full ban on personal phone use in primary schools and strict restrictions at post-primary level. I remember last year when the pouches were introduced, they were ridiculed in here. It was a classic Opposition response.
The time is up Taoiseach. Deputy Cairns to respond.
Some 462 schools have drawn €6 million in respect of that, which shows people have responded positively to the initiative.

This is something governments across the world are grappling with and in many ways the horse has already bolted. Social media companies have been around for 20 years and they have never been properly regulated. To date, it has been self-regulation which has amounted to no regulation at all. Now we are playing catch up.
One things is clear; the algorithms are increasingly dangerous. Violent, racist and misogynistic content is not just tolerated but it is literally boosted by these algorithms, making them go viral.

I recognise there are loads of things in the Taoiseach's list of things the Government is looking at but none of them were the algorithms and a lot of them placed the responsibility on the user and on teaching the user about safety online. What we need to do, as a very first and obvious step, is address the algorithms. Will the Taoiseach reconsider, and will he look at this?

We will be examining all aspects of this, including the impacts and use of algorithms to direct people to certain areas. That clearly is an issue. In terms of legislation, that is already in place in the powers Coimisiún na Meán has. In terms Digital Services Act, in particular, we are in a position to hold platforms to account. The European Commission has launched investigations into the influence of these powerful algorithms, especially on young users online. The European Commission is already working on that aspect.
I am asking what the Taoiseach is doing.

We are part of the European Commission. We are part of the European Union. The big row and argument between the US and Europe is that the US thinks we are over-regulating. I do not think we are but that is the US's assertion, that Europe is over regulating in the digital space. The Commission has been very strong.
Thank you, Taoiseach.
So have our regulators as well. We are part of the harmonised regulatory framework.
Thank you, Taoiseach. Deputy Paul Nicholas Gogarty is next.
The Digital Services Act is a game-changer in respect of this.

Today I raise the chronic shortage of radiographers and the related fragile state of our diagnostic imaging capacity. As the Taoiseach is probably aware, the HSE has acknowledged that radiology and radiation therapy departments remain under-resourced, with waiting lists for diagnostic scans continuing to grow. We saw earlier this year a report on RTÉ showing that, despite over 200 radiography graduates qualifying annually, many are being forced to emigrate because of appointments not being made. This is not just poor workforce planning; it could be called a misuse of public finds, wasting money training professionals who we then lose abroad while we scramble to import more. The HSE radiology workforce report outlines workforce projections and training requirements and recommends increasing the radiology trainee intake from 39 in 2025 to 75 in 2028, highlighting that Ireland's radiologist numbers per capita are substantially below European norms.
